description: An introduction to academic writing and to the genres of narrative, critical, and essay writing. Emphasis will be placed on developing an effective writing process, reading critically, developing arguments, and using and citing sources. Some emphasis on oral presentations may be included.
title: Academic Writing for Specialized Audiences I (Introductory)

description: An introduction to inquiry-based research writing, from formulating good research questions to conducting an information search, developing an argument, using sources effectively, and revising and editing. A focus on oral presentations may also be included.
title: Academic Writing for Specialized Audiences II (Introductory)

description: An intermediate level course in the writing styles, genres, and modes of evidence and reasoning appropriate to academic writing in a specific discipline or disciplines. Emphasis will be placed on connections between reading, writing, critical reasoning, and, where appropriate, other discourse forms such as oral and electronic presentation.
title: Academic Writing for Specialized Audiences (Intermediate)

description: Introduction to accounting for business organizations. Reporting of financial results of operations and financial position to investors, managers, and others. Emphasis on the use of accounting information for decision making.
title: Introductory Financial Accounting
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business Bachelor of Commerce program, successful completion of 12 units (2.0 full-course equivalents) including Mathematics 249 or 251 or 265 or 281.

description: Introduction to basic accounting principles and practices. Emphasis is placed on the accounting cycle and the key financial statements necessary for business decisions. Introduces basic financial and managerial accounting concepts.
title: Accounting Principles
prereqs: Successful completion of 24 units (4.0 full-course equivalents) including Entrepreneurship and Innovation 201.

description: An introduction to the use of accounting within an organizational context. Emphasis is placed on the development and dissemination of accounting information necessary for effective management including: planning, directing, motivating, and controlling activities and behaviours.
title: Introductory Managerial Accounting
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, and Accounting 217 or 317.

description: Financial accounting from a producer point of view. Topics include cash, receivables, inventories, short and long-term investments, intangible assets and capital assets including the appropriate financial statement considerations.
title: Intermediate Financial Accounting I
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Accounting 217 or 317, and 323.

description: Financial accounting from a producer point of view. Topics include accounting for liabilities, shareholders equity, leases, future income taxes, pensions, accounting changes and earnings per share including the relevant financial statement considerations.
title: Intermediate Financial Accounting II
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Accounting 341.

description: The production of accounting data for the purpose of decision-making, control and evaluation. Topics covered are in the cost classifications and methods of cost establishment, cost data appropriate for decision models, standards and controls.
title: Cost Accounting
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Accounting 323.

description: Taxation levied on profits, sales, property and estates and its impact upon management decisions. Consideration will be given to the biases and shifts implicit in any system of taxation.
title: Taxation
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, and successful completion of 54 units (9.0 full-course equivalents) including Accounting 217 or 317.

description: Focuses on tax planning. Extends the material covered in the introductory tax course with an examination of specialized topics in personal and corporate income tax. Topics include detailed review of taxation of corporations, income trusts, partnerships, business reorganization, amalgamations, winding-up of businesses, sale of an incorporated business, tax consequences of leaving Canada and death of a taxpayer.
title: Advanced Taxation
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Accounting 421.

description: A conceptual study of audit evidence, basic audit techniques, professional ethics, audit reports.
title: Auditing
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and successful completion of 54 units (9.0 full-course equivalents) including Accounting 341.

description: Topics include accounting for business combinations and intercorporate investments, foreign currency transactions and translation, bankruptcy, partnerships, and not-for-profit organizations.
title: Advanced Financial Accounting
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and successful completion of 54 units (9.0 full-course equivalents) including Accounting 343.

description: Examines the origins of financial accounting and current theories on the use of financial accounting information by investors, regulators, standard setters, and other corporate stakeholders.
title: Accounting Theory
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and successful completion of 54 units (9.0 full-course equivalents) including Accounting 343.

description: Case approach to Management Control Systems explaining the use of accounting data from a managerial perspective. Emphasis is placed on how managers use planning and control to accomplish a firm's strategies.
title: Managerial Control Systems
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and successful completion of 54 units (9.0 full-course equivalents) including Accounting 361.

description: Investigation of selected topics in Accounting.
title: Selected Topics in Accounting
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and successful completion of 54 units (9.0 full-course equivalents) including Accounting 343.

description: Introduction to accounting for business organizations. Reporting of financial results of operations and financial position to investors, managers, and others. Emphasis on the use of accounting information for decision-making.
title: Introductory Financial Accounting

description: Breakeven analysis, activity-based costing and management, budgeting, productivity measures, and other tools and techniques that are part of a planning and control system that will help the manager make better economic decisions.
title: Management Accounting

description: Provides detailed coverage of the Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) primarily related to assets. Emphasizes the theory behind the methods, the strengths and weaknesses of such methods and the need for sound professional judgment.
title: Intermediate Financial Accounting I
prereqs: Accounting 601 and 603; or consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

description: Builds on Intermediate Financial Accounting I with coverage of the Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) primarily related to liabilities and owners' equity. Emphasizes the theory behind the methods, the strengths and weaknesses of methods and the need for sound professional judgment.
title: Intermediate Financial Accounting II

description: Provides intermediate level discussions to the production and analysis of costs used for pricing, production and investment decisions, revenue analysis, performance evaluation, management incentive systems and strategy analysis.
title: Cost Accounting

description: Discusses the core concepts, regulations, and interpretations underlying the Canadian individual and corporate income taxation. Emphasis is on who is taxable, on what income, when and how tax is calculated. Tax planning opportunities will be identified by using long-term and clientele-based techniques.
title: Taxation

description: Focuses on tax planning. It extends the material covered in the introductory tax course with an examination of specialized topics in personal and corporate income tax.
title: Advanced Taxation

description: Discusses the techniques and theory behind the external auditor's provision of assurance services on financial information. Topics include: the demand for assurance, the role of auditors in providing assurance, auditor independence, audit reports, and audit liability.
title: Auditing

description: Covers the theories, concepts and practices of financial statement analysis with an emphasis placed on applications.
title: Financial Statement Analysis

description: Focuses on advanced accounting methods related to inter-corporate investments and financial reporting. Topics include accounting for business combinations and inter-corporate investments, foreign currency transactions and translation, bankruptcy, partnerships, and not-for-profit organizations.
title: Advanced Financial Accounting

description: Examines the conceptual framework underlying the preparation of financial accounting information, and the theories and propositions on the use of such information by investors, regulators, standard setters, and other corporate stakeholders.
title: Accounting Theory

description: Emphasis is placed on how managers use planning and control to accomplish a firm's strategies. Uses a case approach to management control systems explaining the usefulness of accounting data from a managerial perspective.
title: Managerial Control Systems

description: Development of and solutions to current issues and problems in accounting.
title: Seminar in Accounting
prereqs: Accounting 603 or consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

description: Advanced accounting research topics.
title: Advanced Seminar in Accounting
prereqs: Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

description:
799.01. Seminar in Financial Accounting 
		799.02. Seminar in Managerial Accounting 
		799.04. Seminar in Taxation
title: Doctoral Seminars in Accounting

description: Measurement of interest, elementary annuities, general annuities, amortization schedules and sinking funds, bonds and other securities.
title: Theory of Interest/Mathematics of Finance
prereqs: One of Mathematics 253 or 267 or 277 or 283 or Applied Mathematics 219; or one of Mathematics 249 or 251 or 265 or 275 or 281 or Applied Mathematics 217 with the permission of the Department.

description: The survival function, force of mortality, life tables, analytical laws of mortality, life insurance, continuous and discrete life annuities, recursion equations. Introduction to benefit premiums and/or insurance and annuity models with interest as a random variable as time permits.
title: Life Contingencies I
prereqs: A grade of "C" or higher in Mathematics 321 or Statistics 321.

description: Selected topics relevant to students with an interest in actuarial science, enterprise risk management, financial mathematics, etc. Topics include financial instruments; sources and cost of capital; portfolio selection; CAPM and alternatives; dividend policy; taxation; basic option pricing theory; stock valuation; measurement and assessment of financial performance; risk management.
title: Intermediate Topics in Finance and Investment
prereqs: Actuarial Science 325 and Mathematics 323 or Statistics 323; or Actuarial Science 325 and completion of at least 60 units (10 full-course equivalents) and with the permission of the Department.

description: Benefit premiums, premium principles, fully continuous and fully discrete premiums. Benefit reserves and their analysis. Insurance models including expenses.
title: Life Contingencies II
prereqs: Mathematics 323 or Statistics 323; and one of Mathematics 353 or 367 or 377 or 381; and Actuarial Science 327.

description: Preparation and testing of graduations of mortality tables; graduation by the moving-weighted average, graphic, Whittaker, Bayesian, parametric and smooth-junction interpolation methods; use of statistical methods for graduation.
title: Mathematics of Graduation
prereqs: Actuarial Science 327 and Mathematics 323 or Statistics 323.

description: Multiple life functions, dependent and independent models, related annuities and insurances. Multiple decrement models: time until and causes of death. Associated single decrement tables. Applications of  multiple decrement theory. Asset shares. Business and regulatory considerations.
title: Life Contingencies III
prereqs: Actuarial Science 327 and Mathematics 323 or Statistics 323 and Mathematics 353 or 367 or 377 or 381.

description: Distributions useful for modelling insurance loss random variables. Approximations for and estimation of these loss distributions. Point and interval estimation, and tests of statistical hypotheses. Introduction to credibility theory, experience rating and claims reserving. Bayesian inferential techniques. Stochastic simulation and computational techniques.
title: Credibility Theory and Loss Distributions
prereqs: Actuarial Science 327; and Mathematics 323 or Statistics 323.

description: Conventional and adjusted measures of mortality; measures of fertility; measures of morbidity; North American demographic characteristics and trends; evaluation of demographic data; projections for stable and stationary populations; actuarial applications of demographic characteristics and trends.
title: Mathematics of Demography
prereqs: Actuarial Science 327; and Mathematics 323 or Statistics 323.

description: Offered under various subtitles.
title: Special Topics in Actuarial Science
prereqs: Actuarial Science 327; and Mathematics 323 or Statistics 323 and Mathematics 353 or 367 or 377 or 381.

description: An interdisciplinary perspective on the people and ecologies of the African continent. The major theme will be the processes and effects of social, religious, political, economic, historical and cultural change on the lives of Africans.
title: Introduction to African Studies

description: A field course for the in situ interdisciplinary study of a country or region of Africa, emphasizing the geographical, archaeological, historical, cultural, political, economic and artistic aspects. For further information students should contact the Academic Programs Office or the Program Co-ordinator.
title: Field Study in Africa

description: Study of a particular topic(s) or region(s) from an interdisciplinary and comparative perspective. Students will be required to examine how political, social, economic and cultural factors intersect to shape various issues in the African setting.
title: Seminar
prereqs: One of African Studies 301, Anthropology 317, History 401, Political Science 371.

description: Introduction to American Sign Language (ASL) and the culture of deaf people. Covers material in matriculation-level ASL. It teaches basic communication and conversational skills in ASL and is for students with no background in ASL.
title: Beginners’ American Sign Language I

description: Continuation of American Sign Language 201.
title: Beginners’ American Sign Language II

description: Introduction to evolutionary theory and processes, with particular reference to the primates. Topics include primate taxonomy, distribution, reproduction, locomotion, diet, social organization, and evolution, with special emphasis on the path of human evolution.
title: Introduction to Primatology and Human Evolution

description: The nature of human society: its elements, its variability and its perpetuation. Conclusions will be drawn from comparisons of institutions (political, economic, religious, educational and sexual) in both small-scale and large-scale societies.
title: Introduction to Social and Cultural Anthropology

description: An exploration of the history of Aboriginal/state relations, the development of Indian policy, and current efforts of Aboriginal peoples to address historical matters through the critique of the residential school system and the pursuit of self-government, land claims, modern treaties and Aboriginal rights. Includes a critical examination of Canadian historical writing, popular culture, and stereotypes of Indians and will survey contemporary Aboriginal expressions of identity in the arts, literature, cultural performances, and other public contexts.
title: Contemporary Aboriginal Issues in Canada

description: Ways in which differences in cultural values and practices affect the form and nature of interaction between business parties, especially those of differing national/cultural/ethnic backgrounds.
title: Business in Cultural Context

description: Investigation of the major phases of human evolution, with an emphasis on understanding how, when and why specific adaptations evolved. In laboratories, students learn to reconstruct behaviour from anatomical and palaeontological evidence.
title: Human Evolution

description: Primate behaviour and related topics: social dynamics, sociobiology, socio-ecology, dominance, aggression, kinship, sexual behaviour, socialization, learning, cognition, communication, ape language, and conservation.
title: Primate Behaviour

description: Cross-cultural study of human-environment relationships and its application to contemporary problems concerning environmental issues, resource management, and sustainable development.
title: Anthropology of the Environment

description: Traditional societies in sub-Saharan Africa, concentrating on a number of classical social anthropological field work studies.
title: Ethnographic Survey of Africa South of the Sahara

description: Ethnographic survey of the peoples of North Africa, including the Sahara, and historical analysis of their incorporation within the contemporary national states of the region.
title: Ethnographic Survey of North Africa

description: A survey of cultural traditions of Mexico, the Caribbean, and Central and South America as they have evolved since the sixteenth century.
title: Ethnographic Survey of Latin America

description: Diversity of social and cultural patterns in imperial and contemporary times.
title: Culture and Society of China

description: Arranged for various topics in the anthropology of world areas. Consult department for topics in any given year.
title: Ethnographic Survey of Selected World Areas

description: Cross-species and cross-cultural perspective on sex and gender.
title: Sex and Gender

description: Introduction to the practical use of anthropological knowledge and research methods. Includes discussion of the specific challenges of practicing anthropology outside of academia.
title: Working in Anthropology

description: A survey of anthropological approaches to disease, illness and the maintenance of health.
title: Medical Anthropology

description: Comparative global ethnographic survey of militarization processes. Examples will be drawn from contemporary and historical societies, with a particular emphasis on the wide variety of institutions and communities necessary to the production of violence, and on their relationship to the larger society.
title: Militarism and Militarization

description: Examines the individual, clinical, epidemiological, cultural, social, psychological, political, economic, and public policy dimensions of HIV/AIDS along with its meaning and importance on a global level from an anthropological perspective.
title: Anthropology of HIV/AIDS

description: Selected North American Indian cultures in terms of the relationships among basic subsistence adaptations, social, ceremonial, and ideological structures.
title: An Ethnographic Survey of Native North America

description: Cultural dimensions of local and international development policy, programming, and evaluation.
title: Anthropology of Development
prereqs: One of Anthropology 203, Development Studies 201, or Indigenous Studies 201.

description: Historical survey of anthropological thought from the enlightenment to the present.
title: History of Anthropology

description: Contemporary anthropological theoretical perspectives on indigenous and world religions.
title: Magic, Witchcraft, and Gods: Anthropology of Religion

description: Comparative analysis of power, authority, dependency relations, and processes of governance, from the perspective of social anthropology, with primary emphasis on stateless societies and formative states.
title: Political Anthropology

description: Systems of law and social control in both state and non-state societies.
title: Anthropology of Law

description: A study of tribalism, ethnicity, sub-cultures, social networks and related phenomena in urban societies. Attention will be paid to planning and applied urban anthropology.
title: Urban Anthropology

description: Comparative analysis of production, distribution and consumption in small-scale and complex societies; theories of exchange; effects of capitalism upon traditional economies and social organization.
title: Economic Anthropology

description: Study of a variety of theories in Social and Cultural Anthropology, and their implications for research design and field work.
title: Anthropological Theory

description: Changes in the international division of labour and resulting social, cultural, and political effects, with particular attention to the incorporation of small-scale societies.
title: Ethnography of Global-Local Dynamics

description: Examination of select problems in Anthropology. Topics may be drawn from all subfields in the discipline.
title: Special Topics in Anthropology

description: Selected topics in anthropology to be offered to Majors and Honours in their fourth year. Topics for each student to be arranged on the basis of special interest and need.
title: Independent Study

description: Selected topics in anthropology to be offered to Majors and Honours in their fourth year. Topics for each student to be arranged on the basis of special interest and need.
title: Independent Study

description: Adaptation of indigenous societies to their tropical forest habitat, and their transformation under the impact of industrial society.
title: Ecology of Tropical Forest Societies

description: An introduction to research design, data collection, and analysis as used in anthropology. Cross-cultural research design and methods, use of participant observation and personal documents will be emphasized.
title: Methods and Analysis for Anthropology

description: Focus on observational methods and analysis, with practical application in laboratory study at the Calgary Zoo.
title: Method in Primatology

description: An examination of selected issues in the anthropological study of contemporary Latin America.
title: Contemporary Latin American Society

description: Causes and consequences of primate sociality, such as brain structure and evolution, kin recognition, Theory of Mind, social perception and awareness, and similarities and differences in communication and cognition between human and non-human primates.
title: Primate Cognition

description: Comparison of women's roles in China, Japan, and Korea, with particular reference to family structure and economic organization.
title: Women in East Asian Societies

description: Analysis of evolutionary principles and processes (such as natural selection, sexual selection, kin selection, parental investment) as they are applied to the current study of human and non-human primate behaviour. Special emphasis on socioecological approaches to primate behaviour.
title: Evolutionary Anthropology

description: An examination of select problems in the anthropology of health. Topics of course assignments include models of health in Canada, etiological claims in health research, and anthropology of pharmaceuticals.
title: Problems in the Anthropology of Health

description: Advanced topics in the behavioural ecology and conservation biology of non-human primates, including related theory and field techniques.
title: Topics in Primate Behavioural Ecology and Conservation

description: An anthropological approach to soldiering in the aftermath of the Second World War. Questions the idea of a universal soldier, soldiers’ shifting relationship to the nation-state, the rise of privatized warfare and the creation of global military communities. Special attention will be paid to the rise of humanitarian military regimes, military occupation, new technologies of warfare and non-human soldiers.
title: Soldiering: Perspectives on Military Life

description: Examines interactions between housing and social organization in cross-cultural context. Emphasizes the varied types of built form, their cultural meanings, implications for social life within households and for society more broadly, and their political and economic consequences. Pays particular attention to contemporary housing problems such as homelessness and urban sprawl.
title: Housing and Society

description: Arranged for various topics of anthropology on the basis of special interest and need.
title: Conference Course in Anthropology
prereqs: Anthropology 203 and one additional senior Anthropology  course and consent of the Department.

description: Arranged for various topics of primatology on the basis of special interests and need.
title: Conference Course in Primatology
prereqs: Anthropology 311 and one additional senior primatology course and consent of the Department.

description: Current directions in various subfields of human ecology as they apply to Anthropology, Archaeology, and Geography.
title: Human Ecology

description: Historical and theoretical survey of ideas about the biological bases of human and non-human primate social behaviour. Impacts of the theoretical models of the modern synthesis, ethology, behavioural ecology, socio-ecology, and sociobiology or the study of human and non-human primates.
title: History and Theory in Primatology and Physical Anthropology

description: Research projects carried out off campus, under the supervision of a member of academic staff, and resulting in a graded project report.
title: Field Study in Social and Cultural Anthropology

description: Intensive training and practice in field methods of observational primate behaviour or behavioural ecology.
title: Field Studies in Primatology
prereqs: Anthropology 413 and consent of the Department.

description: Design of a research project, including the identification and operationalization of a research question and the collection and analysis of data.
title: Primate Behavioural Research Design
prereqs: Anthropology 413 and consent of the Department.

description: Current theoretical and methodological issues will be explored in a discussion-based seminar format.
title: Honours Seminar in Primatology
prereqs: Anthropology 413 and admission to the Anthropology Honours Program.

description: Current theoretical and methodological issues will be explored in a discussion-based seminar format, with the possibility of development of a research project.
title: Honours Seminar in Social and Cultural Anthropology
prereqs: Anthropology 411 and admission to the Anthropology Honours Program.

description: The study of human dietary practices from biological and cultural perspectives. Subjects covered include the development of nutritional anthropology, principles of nutrition, principles of ecology, diet from an evolutionary, comparative and historic perspective, the impact of undernutrition on human physiology, and behaviour and methods in nutritional anthropology.
title: Nutritional Anthropology
prereqs: Anthropology 201 or Archaeology 203 or Archaeology 305, and consent of the Department.

description: A specialized area of Anthropology selected on the basis of particular interest and need.
title: Conference Course in Anthropology

description: A reading and conference course in the student's substantive area conducted jointly by at least two faculty members.
title: Thesis Development

description: Training and practice in research/teaching skills: grantsmanship, conference and classroom presentations, academic publishing, job interviews.
title: Professional Skills for Anthropologists

description: A variety of topics relevant to research and the logic of inquiry in Anthropology.
title: Methods in Anthropological Research

description: A variety of topics relating to aspects of data collection and data analysis in primatology, with a focus on ecological and behavioural data.
title: Current Issues in Methodology in Primatology

description: Seminar dealing with the theoretical material of primatological and biobehavioural perspectives in Anthropology.
title: Primatological Theory

description: Comparative analysis of relations between civil society and military institutions. A critical approach to analysing how civil and military institutions mutually constitute each other, rather than taking the military and civilian sectors as a given. Special attention will be paid to twentieth century militarization as a social process that has dramatically changed the shape of both civilian and military spheres.
title: Seminar in Civil-Military Relations

description: Specialized topics and laboratory training in this field will vary from year to year and may include: behavioural ecology, biomechanics, evolution, biosociality, and field methodology.
title: Primatology

description: Classification of ordinary differential equations, first and second order equations with applications, series solutions about regular points and singular points, special functions, Laplace transform.
title: Differential Equations I
prereqs: Mathematics 253 or 267 or 277 or 283 or Applied Mathematics 219.

description: Existence and uniqueness theorems, comparison and oscillation theorems, Green's functions, Sturm-Liouville problems, systems of equations, phase portraits, stability.
title: Differential Equations II
prereqs: One of Mathematics 375, Applied Mathematics 311 or 307; and one of Mathematics 331, 353, 367, 377, 381, Applied Mathematics 309.

description: Orthogonal sets of functions, Fourier series, solution of potential equation, heat equation and wave equation. Numerical solution of partial differential equations.
title: Introduction to Partial Differential Equations
prereqs: One of Mathematics 353, 367, 375, 381, Applied Mathematics 307 or 309 or 311, Mathematics 331.

description: Mathematical analysis of linear systems. Fourier and Laplace transforms, applications and numerical methods. Functions of a complex variable and applications.
title: Mathematical Methods
prereqs: One of Applied Mathematics 311, 307, Mathematics 331, 353, 367, 375, 381, or Applied Mathematics 309.

description: Examples of optimization problems. Quadratic forms, minimum energy and distance. Least squares, generalized inverse. Location and classification of critical points. Variational treatment of eigenvalues. Lagrange multipliers. Linear programming.
title: Introduction to Optimization
prereqs: Mathematics 311 or 313; and one of Mathematics 331 or 353 or 367 or 377 or 381 or Applied Mathematics 309.

description: Fourier analysis. Laplace Transforms. Partial differential equations. Complex analysis. Residue integrals.  Extensive physical applications.
title: Mathematical Methods in Physics
prereqs: Applied Mathematics 307 or 311 or Mathematics 375; and one of Applied Mathematics 309 or Mathematics 353 or 367 or 377 or 381 or 331; and Mathematics 211 or 213.

description: This course is an introduction to the fundamental concepts of mathematical finance in an elementary setting. Topics include: risk, return, no arbitrage principle; basic financial derivatives: options, forwards and future contracts; risk free assets, time value of money, zero coupon bonds; risky assets, binomial tree model, fundamental theorem of asset pricing; portfolio management and capital asset pricing model; no arbitrage pricing of financial derivatives; hedging.
title: Introduction to Mathematical Finance

description: Interpolation and approximation, numerical integration, numerical methods for the solution of non-linear equations, systems of linear equations and the eigenvalue problem.
title: Numerical Analysis I
prereqs: Mathematics 311 or 313 and 381 or 367 or 377 or 349 and 353 or Applied Mathematics 309; and Computer Science 231 or 217.

description: Numerical differentiation, numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations.
title: Numerical Analysis II
prereqs: Applied Mathematics 311, 413, and 491 or Computer Science 491.

description: Topics will be chosen according to the interests of instructors and students and could include analysis of optimization algorithms, approximation theory, control theory, differential equations, mathematical physics.
title: Seminar in Applied Mathematics

description: Continuous and discrete Fourier transforms, the Fast Fourier Transform, wavelet transforms, multiresolution analysis and orthogonal wavelet bases, and applications.
title: The Mathematics of Wavelets, Signal and Image Processing

description: Integral and differential calculus on manifolds including tensor fields, covariant differentiation, Lie differentiation, differential forms, Frobenius' theorem, Stokes' theorem, flows of vector fields.
title: Calculus on Manifolds
prereqs: Pure Mathematics 445 or 545; and one of Mathematics 375 or Applied Mathematics 311 or 307.

description: Mathematical theories of space and time. Special Relativity. Electro-dynamics. General Relativity.
title: Introduction to Relativity Theory

description: Symplectic geometry, Hamilton's equation, Hamilton-Jacobi theory, constraints and reduction.
title: Analytical Dynamics

description: Martingales in discrete and continuous time, risk-neutral valuations, discrete- and continuous-time (B,S)-security markets, Cox-Ross-Rubinstein formula, Wiener and Poisson processes, Ito formula, stochastic differential equations, Girsanov’s theorem, Black-Scholes and Merton formulas, stopping times and American options, stochastic interest rates and their derivatives, energy and commodity models and derivatives, value-at-risk and risk management.
title: Stochastic Calculus for Finance

description: Review of financial asset price and option valuation models; model calibration; tree-based methods; finite-difference methods; Monte Carlo simulation; Fourier methods.
title: Computational Finance

description: A comprehensive course for students with no prior knowledge of the language. Includes training in listening, speaking, reading and writing of Modern Standard Arabic in its cultural context.
title: Beginners Arabic I

description: Continuation of Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 202.
title: Beginners Arabic II

description: A comprehensive course that includes further training in listening, speaking, reading and writing Modern Standard Arabic in its cultural context. Development of increased sophistication in language production and cultural understanding.
title: Intermediate Arabic I

description: A continuation of Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 301.
title: Intermediate Arabic II

description: An introduction to Arabic grammar and syntax through readings of classical sources.
title: Reading Classical Arabic

description: Comparative study of Muslim civilization from Africa, the Arab and Persianate world, Asia and the West up to the end of the 18th century.
title: Muslim Civilization I

description: Comparative study of Muslim civilization from Africa, the Arab and Persianate world, Asia, and the West focusing on the developments of the 19th, 20th and 21st centuries.
title: Muslim Civilization II

description: Exploration of the diversity of national and regional cinemas in predominantly Muslim societies of the world.
title: Cinema of Muslim Societies

description: Study of literary texts within the context of the rich, diverse traditions and cultures of predominantly Muslim societies of the world.
title: Literature of Muslim Societies

description: Basic principles of archaeology. How archaeological remains are located, recovered and interpreted.
title: Introduction to Archaeology

description: Survey of the major subfields of physical anthropology including evolution, human paleontology, genetics, osteology and variation, and techniques of data collection.
title: An Introduction to Physical Anthropology

description: An overview of Old and New World archaeology; the emergence of humans; development of humans and culture from hunting/gathering to agricultural and ancient urban societies.
title: Ancient Peoples and Places

description: Prehistoric cultural developments in North America.
title: Archaeology of North America

description: Some of the major problems involved in interpreting modern and recent human diversity. Emphasis is placed on the interaction between human cultural and biological systems and on cultural influences upon human biological diversity. Factors important to archaeological interpretation will be stressed.
title: Human Variation and Adaptation
prereqs: Mathematics 30-1, 30-2, Pure Mathematics 30 or equivalent; Archaeology 203 or Biology 241 or 205.

description: Practical application of modern field techniques in archaeology, including excavation, recording and analysis of sites, artifacts and related materials. (Advanced students are referred to Archaeology 506.)
title: Field Course in Archaeological Techniques

description: Ethnoarchaeology and analogical reasoning in archaeology. Survey of theoretical approaches and field methods. Case studies in several domains of material culture worldwide. Actual and potential contributions to archaeology and anthropology.
title: Introduction to Ethnoarchaeology

description: Survey of the puebloan archaeology of southwestern North America and their pre-puebloan ancestors. Topics include changes in hunter-gatherer mobility and economy, the rise of agriculture in the American Southwest, the rise of integrative communities and religious belief systems, as well as responses to violence, disease, climate change, and the immigration of non-Puebloan outsiders.
title: Archaeology of the Ancient Puebloan Southwest

description: Introduction to Canadian Plains archaeology. Processes of cultural and social change on the northern plains over the last 12,000 years from early hunters of Ice–Age megafauna to tribal level farming societies are explored from a Canadian Plains perspective.
title: Mammoths to Maize, Medicine Wheels and Warriors: Archaeology of the Canadian Plains

description: The rise and achievements of the earliest civilizations in both the Old and New Worlds. Emphasis will be placed on the civilizations of Mesopotamia, Egypt, India, China, Mesoamerica and the Andes.
title: Ancient Civilizations

description: Archaeology is examined in terms of its place in contemporary society. Topics may include the use of archaeological evidence by special interest groups; archaeology as viewed by the media; ethical questions relating to the practice of archaeology.
title: Archaeology and Popular Culture

description: Introduction to the African Stone Age, with emphasis on sub-Saharan Africa. Major cultural developments are explored through archaeological data, as well as other disciplines, including biogeography and geoarchaeology. Topics include early human origins and the behaviour of early humans during the middle Pleistocene, as well as the Later Stone Age. Focus on major chronological events and the cultural processes that characterize the Paleolithic era on the continent.
title: African Stone Age

description: Ancient cultures of Mexico, excluding the Maya, from their beginnings to the historic period. Emphasis on the civilizations of the Olmecs, Zapotecs, Teotihuacanos, Toltecs and Aztecs.
title: Ancient Mexico

description: Ancient Maya, from their beginnings to the historic period. Emphasis on the Classic Maya civilization, from AD 200-900.
title: The Ancient Maya

description: Traditional native cultures of Middle America. Emphasis is on technology, social organization, economic systems, religions, arts and languages, particularly in the culture centres of Mexico.
title: The Legacy of Mesoamerica

description: Content varies according to region in Latin America where course is taught. A general survey of the archaeology of the region and an intensive look at the archaeology of the immediate vicinity, including visits to sites and museums. Individual and group study are interspersed with formal instruction.
title: Regional Studies in Latin American Archaeology

description: Prehistoric cultural development in the tropical areas of South America with particular emphasis on the Amazon Basin.
title: Archaeology of South America: The Lowlands and the Northern Andes

description: The rise of civilization in the Peruvian and Bolivian Andes. Beginning with the first hunting cultures before 8000 B.C., this course reviews the major events and cultural processes which ultimately led to the development of the Inca civilization.
title: Archaeology of South America: The Central Andes

description: A survey of the culture and linguistics of aboriginal South America, with emphasis on the lowland regions.
title: Native Cultures of the Amazon

description: Traditional cultures of the Ecuadorian, Peruvian and Bolivian Andes. Special emphasis is placed on the social, political and economic organizations of the Inca empire.
title: The Incas and Their Successors

description: African archaeology from the earliest times to the ethnographic present, particularly on Holocene cultures, including hunters and foragers, sedentary farmers, and urban societies.
title: African Archaeology

description: The ethnohistory of the area. Emphasis will be placed on a study of the material culture of non-industrial societies both in the present and the recent past, language distribution, oral tradition and other aspects of ethnohistory.
title: Ethnohistory of Africa

description: Survey of the prehistory of the Near East, starting with the earliest traces of human activity up to the Bronze Age. Topics include adaptations to a varied environment, successive human migrations out of Africa, the nature of the Middle-Upper Palaeolithic transition, the agricultural revolution, and the world’s earliest cities and states.
title: Archaeology of the Near East

description: Overview of Mesoamerican writing systems, including Maya hieroglyphics.  Topics include the origin and development of writing in Mesoamerica, as well as the evolution of the calendar and other notational systems.  Introduction to methods of decipherment and current interpretations of the texts.
title: Mesoamerican Writing Systems

description: Characteristics of soils and the processes and factors of soil formation. Soil development related to geomorphic materials, geomorphic events, anthropogenic sources, and erosional and depositional landscapes.
title: Soil Characteristics and Formation
prereqs: Mathematics 30-1 or Pure Mathematics 30 or equivalent and Geography 313.

description: Study and analysis of tools and other artifacts, including their forms, methods of manufacture and use.
title: Lithic Technology

description: The study and analysis of osteological remains used in reconstructing the subsistence strategies of past peoples.
title: Zooarchaeology

description: From the Blackfoot in the North to the Apache in the south, the lifeways of Plains people were incredibly diverse, including the iconic buffalo hunting people of the western Plains as well as the horticultural people of the eastern Plains. Explores traditional Plains culture as recorded in anthropological ethnographies, early European written accounts, and First Nations oral traditions.
title: Tipi, Buffalo, and Vision: People of the Plains

description: Prehistory/history of N. E. Asia, Alaska, Canada and Greenland. Emphasis will be placed on ecological and ethnographical data.
title: Archaeology of the Arctic

description: A global survey of Old World prehistoric hunter-gatherers with an emphasis on factual data, analytical techniques, and interpretive trends in the study of the Paleolithic era.
title: Paleolithic Archaeology in the Old World

description: Ancient African complex societies with an emphasis on state development south of the Sahara. Topics include why these states developed, their participation in internal and international systems of exchange, technological developments, belief systems that supported power structures, and the reasons for their collapse. Time period covered is from the rise of the ancient state of Egypt to the colonial period.
title: African Complex Societies

description: An overview of the history of hunter-gatherer studies in anthropology and archaeology. Introduces current theoretical issues in hunter-gatherer research.
title: Hunter-Gatherer Archaeology

description: A survey of contemporary approaches to the study of archaeology emphasizing concepts from other disciplines.
title: Introduction to Method and Theory
prereqs: Archaeology 201 and third-year standing or higher.

description: Analytical methods used in geoarchaeology. The interpretation of site and regional context, provenance, and paleoenvironment, and the application of dating methods, chemical and isotopic methods, and remote sensing. Case studies and experiential learning through field examples.
title: Fundamentals of Geoarchaeology
prereqs: Archaeology 201 or Geography 211 or Geology 201 or Geology 209.

description: Comprehensive overview of early hunter-gatherer archaeology in North and South America, including the Clovis/pre-Clovis debate, theoretical issues surrounding early hunting and mobility, the migration to the Americas during the last ice age, and cultural ecological dynamics.
title: Paleoindian Archaeology

description: The production of pottery: raw materials and techniques. Form, function and decoration. Ceramic ecology. Field processing and sampling. Classification: a survey of approaches. Ceramics and archaeological inference. Practical exercises.
title: Ceramic Analysis

description: The theoretical background for feminist archaeology and some of the important advances in Old and New World gender studies. Topics include the relationship of gender hierarchy to the rise of the state; contrasts between the ideological representation of gender and culture practice; and an overarching theme of critical analysis relating the present to the past.
title: Gender in Prehistory

description: Topics of debate in archaeology and human biology from a perspective that emphasizes philosophical, theoretical and methodological issues. Designed to hone students' critical, analytical, and debating skills, and as preparation for graduate studies.
title: Topics of Debate

description: As a continuation of Archaeology 306, students are offered training in the more advanced aspects of field work.
title: Advanced Archaeological Field Techniques

description: The study of the uses of plants for food and other purposes such as tools by people in the past through archaeological remains and ethnobotanical research with contemporary people. Macroscopic and microscopic plant remains, such as phytoliths, starch grains, seeds, and charcoal are employed to reconstruct the past environments of ancient people. Theoretical and ethnobotanical issues such as folk taxonomy and ownership of traditional knowledge are explored.
title: Paleoethnobotany

description: Archaeological plains cultures and the methodological and theoretical issues involved in the use of archaeological reconstructions of the past. Normally, focus will be on the Canadian Plains.
title: Reconstructing Plains Culture

description: Current directions in various subfields of human ecology as they apply to Anthropology, Archaeology, and Geography.
title: Human Ecology

description: This course is offered periodically to meet special needs of students or visiting faculty members.
title: Special Topics in Archaeology

description: This course is offered periodically to meet special needs of students or visiting faculty members.
title: Special Topics in Analytical Archaeology

description: Focus will be on particular time periods or themes in Mesoamerican archaeology and ethnohistory.
title: Topics in Mesoamerican Archaeology

description: The prehistory and history of the indigenous peoples of the Caribbean from the first peopling of the islands to the early contact period.
title: Caribbean Prehistory

description: Introduction to identification and interpretation of human skeletal and dental remains. Emphasis is on functional anatomy and reconstruction of prehistoric lifeways.
title: Human Osteology

description: The study of human dietary practices from biological and cultural perspectives. Subjects covered include the development of nutritional anthropology, principles of nutrition, principles of ecology, diet from an evolutionary, comparative and historic perspective, the impact of undernutrition on human physiology, and behaviour and methods in nutritional anthropology.
title: Nutritional Anthropology
prereqs: Mathematics 30-1, 30-2, Pure Mathematics 30 or equivalent; Anthropology 201 or Archaeology 203 or Archaeology 305, and consent of the Department.

description: Human perceptions and uses of the ecophysical and cultural environment. How societies humanize their environment by naming places, identifying resources, establishing paths, modifying and replicating the natural landscape thereby creating a tradition of land use that can be accessed archaeologically.
title: Landscape Archaeology

description: Human perceptions and uses of the built environment, particularly residential architecture. The emphasis is on the structure and symbolism associated with the spatial arrangements of objects, activities, and social interactions.
title: Household Archaeology

description: Patterns of disease in prehistoric human populations with consideration to the interaction of health and nutrition. Techniques for determining disease and nutrition from prehistoric remains are covered.
title: Problems in Palaeopathology and Palaeonutrition
prereqs: Mathematics 30-1, 30-2, Pure Mathematics 30 or equivalent; Archaeology 203. Archaeology 555 is recommended.

description: Thesis normally required of Honours BSc students and also open for credit to other undergraduate Majors. Students are expected to carry out an analytical research project on a subject acceptable to the Department and to produce a final report written in a professional manner. Normally the project will be directed by one staff member who will consult with another staff member in arriving at an evaluation of the report.
title: Honours Thesis (BSc)

description: An independent reading course for archaeology Majors. Each student is required to choose reading in consultation with an advisor.
title: Independent Reading Course

description: Thesis normally required of Honours BA students and also open for credit to other undergraduate Majors. Students are expected to carry out a research project in a subject acceptable to the Department and to produce a final report written in a professional manner. Normally, the project will be directed by one staff member who will consult with another staff member in arriving at an evaluation of the report.
title: Honours Thesis (BA)

description: An independent reading course for archaeology majors. Emphasis will be on the methodological, technical and scientific literature relating to archaeological interpretation. Each student is required to choose reading in consultation with an advisor.
title: Independent Readings in Archaeology

description: The philosophy of science, the history of anthropological theory, and a survey of contemporary theoretical approaches in anthropology. Throughout, the relevance to and connections with the subdisciplines of archaeology and biological anthropology will be emphasized.
title: Theoretical Foundations

description: Intensive study of special problems of particular interest to Archaeology Department graduate students. Subject matter for any particular year to be left to the discretion of the Department.
title: Seminar on Special Topics

description: Methods of analysing human remains from archaeological contexts with emphasis on identification and description. Lecture, lab and weekly seminar directed to Archaeology graduate students who have not had a previous course in human osteology.
title: Analysis of Human Skeletal Remains

description: The history of archaeological theory and contemporary theoretical and methodological approaches used in archaeological research.
title: Topics in Archaeological Theory and Method

description: Basic issues in the study of human adaptation with a focus on principles of evolutionary biology as they apply to modern studies. Throughout, a bio-cultural approach will be emphasized.
title: Theory and its Application in Biological Anthropology

description: Current developments in interpretation of human skeletal and dental remains. Topics include forensic anthropology, bone biology, and population reconstruction.
title: Advanced Topics in Human Osteology

description: Seminar on selected topics relating to ethnoarchaeology.
title: Problems in Ethnoarchaeology

description: Intensive study of contemporary and prehistoric hunter-gatherer social and economic adaptations.
title: Hunter-Gatherer Adaptations

description: Intensive study of the origins of agriculture throughout the world.
title: Origins of Agriculture

description: The rise, development, and collapse of complex societies throughout the world.
title: The Development of Complex Societies

description: Theory and practice for specialized analyses of the physical and chemical composition of archaeological materials, including microscopic traces of use. Topics will cover procedures used to prepare materials for such specialized analyses and to identify the relevant properties, as well as issues of quantification and interpretation.
title: Specialized Analyses of Archaeological Materials

description: Social identity is a fundamental theoretical and practical concern for archaeologists, physical anthropologists, and paleoanthropologists. Explores how humans use material culture and material practices to interact in a world ordered by social identities. Students will explore how research in their area of interest has addressed social identities.
title: Social Identity

description: Ancient history of Mesoamerica, emphasizing a conjunctive approach based on hieroglyphic, historical and ethnohistorical sources as well as on archaeological evidence.
title: Mesoamerican Archaeology and History

description: Methods and applications of stable isotope analysis to archaeological research. Topics to be covered include the use of light stable isotopes to determine past and present diet, the use of stable isotopes to document residence and migration, analysis of stable carbon isotopes in soils, stable isotope ecology for environmental reconstruction and paleoclimate studies.
title: Stable Isotope Methods in Archaeology

description: Archaeology of particular geographical areas such as Circumpolar, North America, Mesoamerica, South America, Africa, Oceania, and Europe and Near East.
title: Special Topics in World Archaeology

description: An introduction to architecture as an artistic and scientific endeavour as well as an examination of its purpose and intentions, its processes, and its products. Students will develop an understanding of the social, cultural, historical, technological, economic, and natural context influencing the design of buildings and other objects.
title: Introduction to Architectural Studies

description: The principle of sustainability recognizes people as temporary stewards of their environments, working toward a respect for natural systems and a higher quality of life. Examination of the built environment and the tools to achieve a stable and balanced and a regenerative ecosystem in a process of responsible consumption, wherein waste is minimized and the built environment interacts with natural environments and cycles. Healthful interior environments, resource efficiency, ecologically benign materials, renewable energies and social justice issues are examined.
title: Sustainability in the Built Environment
prereqs: Admission to the Architectural Studies Minor, or consent of the Faculty.

description: An introduction to the application of ordering principles of architecture and to the numerous layers that contributes to the quality of inhabitation of place and space through design. Issues explored include the formal, the experiential and the theoretical concerns of architectural design in today's cultural context.
title: Studio II in Architecture
prereqs: Architectural Studies 451 and 484 and admission to the Architectural Studies Minor, or consent of the Faculty.

description: Functioning of the building enclosure: demonstration of the behaviour of building elements and their sub-assemblies under differential temperature and pressure stresses; fundamentals of acoustics; nature and use of building materials; response of building materials to climatic cycles radiation, precipitation, heating and cooling.
title: Building Science and Technology I
prereqs: Admission to the Architectural Studies Minor, or consent of the Faculty.

description: A skill building course with instruction and supervised experience in basic drafting, sketching and rendering; principles of perspective, drawing and presentation conventions. A variety of instruction may be offered to accommodate the varied level of student development.
title: Graphics Workshop I
prereqs: Admission to the Architectural Studies Minor, or consent of the Faculty.

description: Instruction and supervised experience in drafting, sketching and rendering; drawing and presentation conventions. Builds on Architectural Studies 451. A variety of instruction may be offered to accommodate the varied level of student development.
title: Graphics Workshop II
prereqs: Architectural Studies 451 and 484 and admission to the Architectural Studies Minor, or consent of the Faculty.

description:
A survey history of architecture and human settlement from the prehistoric world until the present. The first course addresses the pre-modern traditions of the major world cultures. The second course explores the traditions of the Western world from the beginning of the Italian Renaissance until the present. The courses will examine the changes in world view that have altered the course of architecture through the study of selected works of architecture and urbanism.
		457.01. History of Architecture and Human Settlements I-Premodern Traditions of the World 
		457.02. History of Architecture and Human Settlements II-The Rise of Modernity, 1750 to the Present
title: History of Architecture and Human Settlements
prereqs: Admission to the Architectural Studies Minor, or consent of the Faculty.

description: Conceptual frameworks in Environmental Design and theories related to design and environment that influence environmental design thinking and practice.
title: Interdisciplinary Seminar
prereqs: Admission to the Architectural Studies Minor, or consent of the Faculty.

description: Foundation concepts in design and form making involving a sequence of progress skill building, visual and spatial thinking and problem solving exercises.
title: Studio I - Design Thinking
prereqs: Admission to the Architectural Studies Minor, or consent of the Faculty.

description: A series of presentations by visiting artists and scholars. Attendance is compulsory.
title: Visiting Artists and Scholars

description: A series of presentations by visiting artists and scholars. Attendance is compulsory.
title: Visiting Artists and Scholars

description: An introduction to the history, theory and philosophy of art education through participatory learning events.
title: Introduction to the Foundations of Art Education
prereqs: Admission into a degree program offered by the Department of Art.

description: Two-dimensional activities and the structural, organizational, perceptual, social and psychological aspects of art.
title: Art Fundamentals: 2D

description: Three-dimensional activities and the structural, organizational, perceptual, social and psychological aspects of art.
title: Art Fundamentals: 3D

description: An introductory course in current photographic methods, including digital photography, digital image processing, film photography, film developing and printing and the presentation of photographs in both digital and paper-based media.
title: Introduction to Photography

description: Basic theory and practice of drawing, involving mainly still life and figure projects in monochromatic media.
title: Drawing I

description: Continuation of Art 241, introducing colour media.
title: Drawing II

description: Technical instruction and creative opportunities in the media arts, in addition to examination of historical, theoretical and critical context.
title: Media Arts: Practice and Theory I

description: Continued technical instruction and creative opportunities in the media arts, in addition to examination of historical, theoretical and critical context.
title: Media Arts: Practice and Theory  II

description: Basic concepts and techniques in Fine Art Printmaking.
title: Introduction to Printmaking

description: Study of recent Canadian art from a range of perspectives in art criticism.
title: Studies in Contemporary Canadian Art

description: Theory and methods of creating meaningful art experiences for young children (ages 3-8), with a practical component.
title: Applied Concepts in Early Childhood Art

description: Theory and methods of creating meaningful art experiences for children aged 6 to 12, with a practical component.
title: Applied Concepts in Art with Children

description: Topics in art may include art appreciation, art and everyday life, themes in art history.
title: Topics in Art

description: Focuses on concepts, issues, and techniques of video as an art medium. Each student will gain experience and a working knowledge of concept development, video shooting and digital editing, in the context of contemporary art theory and practice.
title: Video Art
prereqs: Completion of at least 3 units (0.5 full-course equivalent) in Art.

description: An introduction to computer programming techniques used to create interactive art projects.
title: Programming for Artists
prereqs: Completion of at least 3 units (0.5 full-course equivalent) in Art.

description: Theoretical and practical applications of basic electronic principles and techniques involving the use of electronics in contemporary art practices. Will include applied experiences with hardware and visual programming environments.
title: Electronics for Artists
prereqs: Completion of at least 3 units (0.5 full-course equivalent) in Art.

description: Examination of the work of Net-based artists and investigation of the Internet as a vehicle to extend art and design practice.
title: Net Art: Theory and Practice

description: Electronic visualization involving computer applications in artistic practice.
title: 2D Digital Imaging

description: Exploration of time and duration as a component of artistic practice, that may include the use of frame-based media such as time-lapse photography, stroboscopy, stop-motion, and camera-less animation.
title: Time-Based Art

description: Fundamental technical and aesthetic considerations in the use of the still Digital Single Lens Reflex (DSLR) camera and basic use of the microcomputer in support of digital image processing in art.
title: Digital Photography

description: Further work in photography, using film and silver-based photographic materials including intensive use of the variables of exposure, film development and silver-based printing of photographic materials.
title: Film Photography

description: Investigations into the concepts and practices which have supported theories of colour in the visual arts.
title: Applied Colour Theory

description: Theory and practice of drawing at an intermediate level involving an extended range of drawing media.
title: Drawing III

description: Continuation of Art 341 extending the range of concepts and practices.
title: Drawing IV

description: Perceptual and drawing skills pertaining to human anatomical relationships.
title: Anatomical Drawing I

description: Continuation of Art 345. Further study and work in anatomical drawing.
title: Anatomical Drawing II

description: Basic and more complex principles of drawing from subjects pertaining to the biological sciences; drawing from observation, exploration of foundational skills in a cross-disciplinary context.
title: Drawing for the Biological Sciences

description: Painting on a two-dimensional surface; the use of oils and acrylics.
title: Painting I

description: Further study and work in painting.
title: Painting II

description: Basic concepts and techniques of lithographic printing.
title: Printmaking, Lithography I

description: Basic concepts and techniques of silk-screen printing.
title: Printmaking, Serigraphy I

description: Basic concepts and techniques in relief and intaglio printmaking.
title: Printmaking, Relief and Intaglio

description: Development and realization of sculpture with various techniques and materials.
title: Sculpture I

description: Further study and work in sculpture.
title: Sculpture II

description: Development of teaching rationales and strategies for students aged 12 to 18 with a practical component.
title: Applied Concepts in Art with Adolescents

description: Exploration of materials, processes, concepts and history related to the visual arts. This is a course for non-majors.
title: Introduction to Visual Art I

description: Further exploration of materials, processes, concepts and history related to the visual arts. This is a course for non-majors.
title: Introduction to Visual Art II

description: Theories of art, critical methodologies, and aesthetics in the visual arts.
title: Art in Theory and Practice I

description: Study of recent international art practices from a range of perspectives in art criticism.
title: Studies in Contemporary International Art

description: Focus on the development and production of physical systems-based artwork that incorporate elements of robotics, motion control, software and hardware design.  An introduction to electronic devices for use in artmaking, providing practical experience with sensors, motors, switches, gears, lights, simple circuits and computers to create kinetic and interactive works of art.
title: Mechatronic Art and Design

description: Possible topics include, but are not limited to: Multiculturalism and Art Education, Creativity and Art Education, Developmental Issues in Art Education, Art Education with Special Needs Learners.
title: Selected Topics in Art Education

description: Creative research in 3D digital visualization and fabrication involving multimedia software and hardware. May include 3D printing, rapid prototyping, laser cutting, and computer controlled milling.
title: 3D Digital Imaging

description: Investigation of technical and conceptual aspects of Zone System photography and studio lighting; individual and group study that may include work in film, digital printing and digital photography.
title: Intermediate Photography I

description: Continuing work in photography, with emphasis on hand-coated printing media.
title: Intermediate Photography II

description: Drawing at an intermediate level with an increased emphasis on individual initiative and contemporary concepts in defining objectives.
title: Drawing V

description: Continuation of Art 441.
title: Drawing VI

description: Intermediate work in painting intended to increase ability to deal with painting concepts through appropriate media-technical means.
title: Painting III

description: Continuation of Art 451.
title: Painting IV

description: Directed studio research and production for students admitted to the BFA Honours Visual Studies.
title: Advanced Studio I
prereqs: Consent of Department or admission to the Honours Program.

title: Selected Topics in Studio Research
prereqs: Completion of at least 6 units (1.0 full-course equivalent) in 300-level studio art.

description: Intermediate work in printmaking with an emphasis on technique and a concentration in one of the four (relief, etching, silkscreen, lithography) print media.
title: Intermediate Printmaking: Technique

description: Intermediate work in printmaking with an emphasis on colour and a concentration in one of the four (relief, etching, silkscreen, lithography) print media.
title: Intermediate Printmaking: Colour

description: Problems of three-dimensional form in a variety of materials and techniques.
title: Sculpture III

description: Continuation of Art 481.
title: Sculpture IV

description: A seminar and field experience course introducing prospective educators to all facets of planning and implementing positive art experiences in a non-school setting.
title: Community-Based Art Experiences I

description: Examination and discussion of theoretical issues associated with current practice in art.
title: Art in Theory and Practice II

description: Possible topics include, but are not limited to: Advance Digital Imaging, Sound and Interactivity, Immersive Art, Tele-Arts.
title: Selected Topics in Media Arts

description: The game design process will be explored, including a history of video games, genres, game mechanics, design documents, and a summary of the development process. The focus will be on design, rather than development, and the artistic and creative assets, rather than the software. Students will design a game and will create a playable prototype. The principles will be applicable to other sorts of games, and to media art in general.
title: Computer Game Design

description: Analysis and development of curriculum structure based on current theory with a field research component.
title: Curriculum Building for Art
prereqs: Art 205 and 6 units (1.0 full-course equivalent) in Art.

description: A seminar course devoted to the analysis and design of program structures derived from current theory with a field research component.
title: Designing Programs for Art

description: Photography for advanced students taking individual directions with special attention to the interrelation of technique and aesthetics.
title: Advanced Photography I

description: Photography for advanced students taking individual directions in black and white and colour photography, with emphasis on the presentation of groups of photographs of related theme or technique.
title: Advanced Photography II

description: Drawing for advanced students taking individual directions.
title: Drawing VII

description: Painting for advanced students taking individual directions.
title: Painting V

description: Painting for advanced students taking individual directions.
title: Painting VI

description: Independent studio research and production supported by a research paper for BFA Honours Visual Studies students, culminating in a Thesis Exhibition.
title: Honours Thesis
prereqs: Art 461 and admission to the Honours Program.

description: Directed studio research and production.
title: Advanced Studio II

description: Further directed studio research and production.
title: Advanced Studio III

description: Printmaking for advanced students taking individual directions with emphasis on technique.
title: Advanced Printmaking: Technique

description: Printmaking for advanced students taking individual directions with emphasis on colour.
title: Advanced Printmaking: Colour

description: Sculpture for advanced students taking individual directions. Workshop facilities are available for work in plastics, metal, wood, stone, clay and related materials.
title: Sculpture V

description: A seminar and field experience course in which students take increased individual responsibility for implementation of educational strategies in diverse field settings.
title: Community-Based Art Experiences II

description: Independent studio research.
title: Studio Research

description: Examination and discussion of the issues associated with the professional aspects of surviving as an artist. Presentations by professional artists practicing in the field will form a major component of the course.
title: Professional Aspects of Art

description: Individual study: in consultation with the instructor, the student will select a research topic in art history or art criticism.
title: History of Art I
prereqs: Restricted to MFA or PhD students enrolled in the Art Department.

description: Individual study: in consultation with the instructor, the student will select a research topic in art history or art criticism.
title: History of Art II

description: Individual study and research in the area of studio specialization, critical theory, methodological issues and/or historical topics.
title: Critical Study and Research
prereqs: Restricted to MFA or PhD students enrolled in the Art Department.

description:
Individual weekly study in studio, with seminar-based discussions in research area. The seminar meets every two weeks throughout the entire academic year.
		661.01. Advanced Studio Practice
		661.02. Thesis Studio Practice
title: Advanced Studio Practice
prereqs: For Art 661.01: Restricted to MFA or PhD students enrolled in the Art Department. For Art 661.02, the prerequisite is Art 661.01.

description: Issues in professional practice and post-secondary teaching in visual art. Optional course.
title: Pedagogy and Professional Practice
prereqs: Restricted to MFA or PhD students enrolled in the Art Department.

description: Studies in contemporary art theory and criticism.
title: Topics in Art Theory and Criticism

description: Theoretical and applied concepts in studio.
title: Advanced Independent Studio research
prereqs: Restricted to MFA or PhD students enrolled in the Art Department.

description: A chronological examination of art and architecture in relation to significant historical and cultural events from Pre-history to about 1300 C.E.
title: Survey of Western Art in its Cultural Context: Pre-history to the Later Middle Ages

description: A chronological examination of art and architecture (with some reference to the other arts) in relation to significant historical and cultural events from about 1300 to about 1800.
title: Survey of Western Art in its Cultural Context: Proto-Renaissance to Neo-Classicism

description: A chronological examination of Western art in relation to significant historical and cultural events from WWII to the present
title: Art: World War II to the Present

description: Forms and concepts in art in Canada from the Early French and English Colonial periods to 1900.
title: Art of Canada: 1600-1900

description: Forms and concepts in Canadian art from 1900 to the present; the Group of Seven, Nationalism, Regionalism and more recent developments in Canadian art.
title: Art of Canada: 1900 to the Present

description: A chronological examination of the art and architecture of ancient India and related civilizations, with special emphasis on Buddhist, Hindu and Islamic art.
title: Survey of Far Eastern Art: India and Related Civilizations

description: A chronological examination of the art and architecture of ancient China and related civilizations, with special emphasis on Confucian, Taoist and Buddhist art.
title: Survey of Far Eastern Art: China and Related Civilizations

description: A chronological examination of the arts and architecture from the Proto-Renaissance in Italy to the threshold of the High Renaissance (c. 1300-1500). Special attention will be given to the artistic cultures of Florence and Flanders.
title: Renaissance Art

description: A chronological examination of the arts and architecture from about 1500 to the end of the sixteenth century. Special attention will be given to the key artistic personalities representing the High Renaissance and Mannerism in northern and southern Europe.
title: High Renaissance and Mannerism

description: A chronological examination of the art and architecture during the seventeenth century. Special attention will be given to Rome.
title: Italian Baroque Art

description: A chronological examination of the art and architecture in northern Europe from c. 1600 to 1789.
title: Northern Baroque and Rococo Art

description: A chronological examination of the art and architecture of dynastic Japan, with special emphasis on Shinto and Buddhist traditions.
title: Survey of Far Eastern Art: Japan

description: Survey of the forms and purposes of Native art in Woodlands, Plains, Northwest Coast and Southwest cultures throughout the prehistoric and historic periods and in conjunction with a study of cultural development and change.
title: Native North American Art in its Cultural Context

description: A chronological examination of European painting and sculpture from the late eighteenth century through the Romantic period.
title: Late Eighteenth- and Early Nineteenth-Century Art

description: A chronological examination of European painting and sculpture of the Realist, Impressionist and Post-Impressionist periods.
title: Mid to Late Nineteenth-Century Art

description:
Topics to be announced. Typical topics include: The Art of Michelangelo, Surrealism, Abstract Art in Canada, Painting in New York from WW II to Present, Art of the West African Sudan, The Canadian Landscape.
		411.01. Selected Topics in the History of Art I
		411.02. Selected Topics in the History of Art II
title: Selected Topics in the History of Art
prereqs: Completion of at least 18 units (3.0 full-course equivalents) in Art History.

description: Study of the forms and concepts in painting, sculpture, and architecture from the end of the First World War through the 1950s.
title: Modern Art: From the End of the First World War through the 1950s

description: Origins of photography and its development as technology and art up to 1900.
title: Photography in the Nineteenth Century

description: The development of photography from 1900 to the present, with attention to the theory and criticism of photography as an art form.
title: Photography in the Twentieth Century

description: A survey of significant examples of modern architecture, defining their stylistic character in light of developments in technology, the history of ideas, and social and historical factors.
title: Architecture in the Western World Since 1900

description: Independent research projects for advanced students in art history.
title: Independent Research in Art History I
prereqs: Completion of at least 30 units (5.0 full-course equivalents) in Art History and consent of the Department.

description: Continuation of Art 501.
title: Independent Research in Art History II

description: Topics to be announced. Possible topics include: The Art of Bernini, Cubism, The Group of Seven in Canada.
title: Seminar in the History of Art
prereqs: Completion of at least 24 units (4.0 full-course equivalents) in Art History including 411.

description: Specialized study in an area of art history selected on the basis of particular interest and need.
title: Conference Course in Art History

description: A reading and conference course in the student's research area.
title: Thesis Development

description: Group or individual study topics which involve international experience. Group study topics will vary from year to year.
title: International Study Topics

description: Authorized academic field placements will vary from year to year.
title: Academic Field Placement
