description: Theory, research, and practice in child and family psychotherapy and behaviour change. Supervised exposure to the practice of child and family psychotherapy in a relevant clinical setting.
title: Child Psychotherapy

description: Selected interdisciplinary topics in Psychology. Topics will vary.
title: Integrative Seminar in Psychology

description: Completion of a research project in Brain and/or Cognitive Sciences conducted under the supervision of a faculty member. Topics may vary.
title: Research in Brain and Cognitive Sciences

description: Completion of a research project in the areas of Social and/or Theoretical Psychology conducted under the supervision of a faculty member. Topics may vary.
title: Research in Social and Theoretical Psychology

description: Completion of a research project in Industrial/Organizational Psychology conducted under the supervision of a faculty member. Topics may vary.
title: Research in Industrial/Organizational Psychology

description: Selected interdisciplinary topics in Psychology. Topics may vary.
title: Integrative Seminar in Psychology

description: Completion of a research project in Brain and/or Cognitive Sciences conducted under the supervision of a faculty member. Topics may vary.
title: Research in Brain and Cognitive Sciences

description: Completion of a research project in the areas of Social and/or Theoretical Psychology conducted under the supervision of a faculty member. Topics may vary.
title: Research in Social and Theoretical Psychology

description: Selected topics in Brain and/or Cognitive Sciences. Topics may vary.
title: Seminar in Brain and Cognitive Sciences

description: Selected topics in Social and/or Theoretical Psychology. Topics may vary.
title: Seminar in Social and Theoretical Psychology

description: Application of psychological principles and methods to business, industry and other organizational settings.
title: Seminar in Industrial/Organizational Psychology

description:
A doctoral level seminar in advanced topics in the practice of clinical psychology. 
		750.01. Psychopharmacology
		750.02. Neuropsychology 
		750.05. Diversity Issues in Clinical Psychology 
		750.06. Clinical Geropsychology 
		750.09. Addictions
		750.10. Health Psychology 
		750.11. Eating Disorders
		750.12. Consultation/Supervision
title: Advanced Seminar in Clinical Psychology

description: A specialized topic course in the area of adult psychopathology. Course offerings will vary from year to year and may include such topics as: schizophrenia, substance abuse, suicide, mental health delivery systems, or computer applications in clinical psychology.
title: Special Topics in Adult Psychopathology

description: Supervised training experience in an approved clinical setting. Provides in-depth exposure to specific clinical populations and to the application of various psychological assessment and intervention strategies and techniques.
title: Specialty Practicum in Clinical Psychology I

description: Supervised training experience in an approved clinical setting. Provides advanced in-depth exposure to specific clinical populations and to the application of various psychological assessment and intervention strategies and techniques.
title: Specialty Practicum in Clinical Psychology II

description: Supervised training experience in an approved clinical setting. Provides exposure to specific clinical populations and to the application of various psychological assessment and intervention strategies and techniques.
title: Practicum in Clinical Psychology

description: A full calendar year, full-time (or two-years, half-time) supervised training experience in an approved clinical setting. Intensive exposure to various professional issues, the opportunity to work with a diverse range of clinical populations and problems, and advanced training in the use of specific psychological assessment and intervention strategies.
title: Pre-Doctoral Internship in Clinical Psychology

description: This preparatory course covers the foundations necessary to understand and apply economic analysis and it covers selected topics relevant to the core courses listed below.
title: Foundations I

description: This preparatory course covers the foundations of basic empirical analysis, including quantitative and qualitative research methods.
title: Foundations II

description: The role of markets in the allocation of resources and the determination of income. Sources of market failure, and the appropriate public policy response to those failures, are examined. Students learn how private firms make decisions, and how they respond to policy initiatives.
title: Markets and Public Policy

description: How public policy issues emerge and how they are developed, refined, and influenced by the political process. The roles and influences of NGOs, interest groups, the media, political parties, and social protest on the development of new public policies are examined from the perspective of several disciplines. The importance of agenda setting, management and planning, policy reform and the organizational resistance to change is examined. Models of rational actors and bureaucratic behaviour are explored.
title: Politics and Collective Choice

description: The focus is on the foundations, applications and use of quantitative methods commonly used in decision making in the public and private sectors. Included are methods such as impact analysis, cost-benefit analysis, surveys, game theory and risk management tools.
title: Decision Analysis

description: Supervised individual study in a selected public policy area.
title: Independent Study

description: Development of skills for writing high quality documents in a professional setting. Defining, designing and executing applied, policy-oriented research.
title: Effective Writing and Research Skills

description: An overview of government finances and the restrictions on policy choices resulting from the need for governments to satisfy a budget constraint. Tax policy, the appropriate design of expenditure policies, policies with respect to deficits and debt, and issues of intergovernmental relations will be examined.
title: Public Finances

description: The role of international and national legal institutions in determining public policy choices. Legal research and interpretation skills are developed through specific public policy issues such as the design of market regulation in telecommunications, energy and various utility markets.
title: Regulation and the Law

description: An examination of the rules and informal relationships among those determining public policy outcomes. Alternative institutional relationships and the evolution of those relationships are studied. The ever-changing dynamic of multi-level governance and court versus legislative public policy making are explored.
title: Governance, Institutions and Public Policy

description: Examines all aspects of communication in the context of policy, including the impact of new modes of communication on the development and dissemination of public policy. The new role of blogs, online communities, and web-based media at marshalling and influencing public opinion and the changing role of print media are discussed and evaluated. Implications for copyright policies, media concentration, privacy, and advertising are among the issues examined.
title: Communicating Policy

description: Students learn methods by which research contributes to the design and development of policy outcomes. Students are required to apply the skills they have learned to the completion of a capstone project which investigates a well-defined issue of public policy. The final product of the capstone project is expected to be a substantive, well-researched, focused and highly professional document. Work on the capstone project will be guided by a School of Public Policy faculty member and may include input provided by an expert from the private sector or public sector.
title: Capstone Project

description: Basic ring theory: rings and fields, the integers modulon, Polynomial rings, polynomials over the integers and rationals, homomorphisms, ideals and quotients, principal ideal domains, adjoining the root of an irreducible polynomial; basic group theory: groups, examples including cyclic, symmetric, alternating and dihedral groups, subgroups, cosets and Lagrange’s theorem, normal subgroups and quotients, group homomorphisms, the isomorphism theorems, further topics as time permits, e.g., group actions, Cayley’s theorem.
title: Algebra I

description: Basic ring theory: rings and fields, the integers modulo n, polynomial rings, polynomials over the integers and rationals, homomorphisms, ideals and quotients, principal ideal domains, adjoining the root of an irreducible polynomial; basic group theory: groups, examples including cyclic, symmetric, alternating and dihedral groups, subgroups, cosets and Lagrange’s theorem, normal subgroups and quotients, group homomorphisms, the isomorphism theorems, further topics as time permits, e.g., group actions, Cayley’s theorem.
title: Honours Algebra I

description: Geometric transformations in the Euclidean plane. Frieze patterns. Wallpaper patterns. Tessellations.
title: Transformation Geometry
prereqs: Mathematics 211 or 213 and one other 200-level course labelled Applied Mathematics, Mathematics or Pure Mathematics, not including Mathematics 205.

description: Set theory, mathematical logic, category theory, according to interests of students and instructor.
title: Foundations
prereqs: Mathematics 271 or 273 or 311 or 313 or 353 or 367 or 377 or 381 or Pure Mathematics 315 or 317.

description: The basics of cryptography, with emphasis on attaining well-defined and practical notions of security. Symmetric and public-key cryptosystems; one-way and trapdoor functions; mechanisms for data integrity; digital signatures; key management; applications to the design of cryptographic systems. Assessment will primarily focus on mathematical theory and proof-oriented homework problems; additional application programming exercises will be available for extra credit.
title: Introduction to Cryptography
prereqs: One of Mathematics 271 or 273 or Pure Mathematics 315 or 317.

description: Curvature, connections, parallel transport, Gauss-Bonnet theorem.
title: Differential Geometry

description: Euclidean, convex, discrete, synthetic, projective or hyperbolic geometry, according to interests of the instructor.
title: Geometry

description: Divisibility and the Euclidean algorithm, modular arithmetic and congruences, quadratic reciprocity, arithmetic functions, distribution of primes.
title: Number Theory

description: Review of basic algorithms and complexity. Designing and attacking public key cryptosystems based on number theory. Basic techniques for primality testing, factoring and extracting discrete logarithms. Elliptic curve cryptography. Additional topics may include knapsack systems, zero knowledge, attacks on hash functions, identity-based cryptography, and quantum cryptography.
title: Cryptography – Design and Analysis of Cryptosystems
prereqs: Pure Mathematics 315 or 317; and one of Pure Mathematics 329, 418, Computer Science 418.

description: Group theory: Sylow theorems, solvable, nilpotent and p-groups, simplicity of alternating groups and PSL(n,q), structure theory of finite abelian groups; field theory: gilds, algebraic and transcendental extensions, separability and normality, Galois theory, insolvability of the general quintic equation, computation of Galois groups over the rationals.
title: Algebra II
prereqs: Mathematics 311 or 313 and Pure Mathematics 315 or 317.

description: Counting techniques, generating functions, inclusion-exclusion, introduction to graph theory and the theory of relational structures.
title: Combinatorics and Graph Theory
prereqs: Mathematics 271 or 273; and one of Mathematics 249, 251, 265, 275, 281 or Applied Mathematics 217.

description: According to interests of students and instructor.
title: Topics in Mathematics

description: Basic point set topology: metric spaces, separation and countability axioms, connectedness and compactness, complete metric spaces, function spaces, homotopy.
title: Topology I
prereqs: Pure Mathematics 435 or 455 or Mathematics  335 or 355.

description: Linear algebra: Modules, direct sums and free modules, tensor products, linear algebra over modules, finitely generated modules over PIDs, canonical forms, computing invariant factors from presentations; projective, injective and flat modules.
title: Algebra III

description: Existence of separable and algebraic closures of fields, infinite Galois extensions, profinite groups, Krull topology.
title: Advanced Galois Theory

description: An investigation of major problems in computational number theory, with emphasis on practical techniques and their computational complexity. Topics include basic integer arithmetic algorithms, finite fields, primality proving, factoring methods, algorithms in algebraic number fields.
title: Computational Number Theory

description: Cryptography based on quadratic residuacity. Advanced techniques for factoring and extracting discrete logarithms. Hyperelliptic curve cryptography. Pairings and their applications to cryptography. Code-based and lattice-based cryptography. Additional topics may include provable security, secret sharing, more post-quantum cryptography, and new developments in cryptography.
title: Advanced Cryptography and Cryptanalysis

description: Discrete aspects of convex optimization; computational and asymptotic methods; graph theory and the theory of relational structures; according to interests of students and instructor.
title: Discrete Mathematics

description: Readings (in English translation) from the classical literatures of middle Eastern and Asian religions. Introduction to the evolving mythological traditions from three geo-cultural centres (the middle East, India, and China) by examining religious themes: cosmology; existential values and goals; destinies of humans, the world, and the cosmos.
title: Religious Myths and Worldviews

description: Introduction to Judaism, Christianity and Islam.
title: Jews, Christians and Muslims

description: Introduction to Eastern religions such as Jainism, Hinduism, Sikhism, Buddhism, Confucianism and Taoism.
title: Asian Religions

description: An introduction to the academic study of religion with particular emphasis on the nature of religion, its role as a response to existential questions, and the relationship of religion to contemporary thought and culture.
title: Religion and The Good Life

description: Classical or Biblical Hebrew language; the development of ability in the critical reading of ancient texts. No attempt will be made to provide any competence in medieval or modern Hebrew.
title: Classical Hebrew I

description: An introduction to the critical study and reading of the books of the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament in English translation. The course focuses on the Bible as religious literature.
title: Studies in the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament

description: Continuation of Religious Studies 300.
title: Classical Hebrew II

description: The history, textual traditions, schools and sectarian traditions of Hinduism.
title: Introduction to Hinduism

description: A survey of religious beliefs and practices in the pre-Christian Greek World.
title: Greek Religion
prereqs: One of Greek and Roman Studies 205, 209, Religious Studies 201, or 205.

description: An introductory survey of the contemporary practices of Hinduism in South Asia and in diaspora Hindu communities throughout the world. Focusing on recent ethnographic research, the course examines the diversity of popular Hindu practices with special attention to differences defined by region, language, caste, and gender. Topics covered will include, but are not limited to, the structure of social and family life, the organization of sacred space and time, ritual practices, and the influence and impact of modernity in Hindu life.
title: Popular Hinduism

description: A study of philosophical and psychological theories of the nature and function of religious experiences and an introduction to a variety of religious experiences, which may include theophany, mysticism, enlightenment, conversion, and guilt.
title: Religious Experience

description: Classical Sanskrit language; the development of ability in the critical reading of ancient Hindu or Buddhist texts.
title: Sanskrit I

description: Continuation of Religious Studies 310.
title: Sanskrit II

description: Buddhist developments from the time of Buddha to the development of Mahayana.
title: Introduction to Buddhism

description: Classical Tibetan language; the development of ability in the critical reading of ancient Bon and Buddhist texts.
title: Tibetan I

description: Continuation of Religious Studies 314.
title: Tibetan II

description: An in-depth survey of the religious traditions of the Indian sub-continent. Special attention will be given to the long history of religious pluralism and recent communal conflicts in South Asia. The course will cover religious traditions that have come to South Asia from other parts of the world (primarily Islam, but also Zoroastrianism, Judaism, Christianity and Baha’i).
title: Religion in South Asia

description: The development of Vajrayana, Tantric and other esoteric traditions of Buddhismin India, Tibet, China, Japan and in the West from medieval times to the present.
title: Esoteric Buddhism

description: Introduction to Classical Chinese language, with emphasis on developing the ability to read ancient Chinese religious texts.
title: Classical Chinese for Religious Texts I

description: Continuation of Religious Studies 320.
title: Classical Chinese for Religious Texts II

description: Mahayana developments in India, China, Tibet or Japan.
title: Mahayana Buddhism

description: Feminine images in religions such as goddesses, women as saintly persons, the ultimate in female symbols.
title: Female Saints, Images and Sacred Figures in World Religions

description: The religious developments in Tibet, with emphasis on religious history, literature and philosophy and their contemporary implications.
title: Tibetan Religious Traditions

description: The history, doctrines, literature and leading figures of Buddhism in China and Japan.
title: Buddhism in East Asia

description: An examination of various religious perspectives on the nature and causes of human suffering.
title: Religious Perspectives on Suffering

description: An examination of various religious perspectives on the nature of death and life after death.
title: Religious Perspectives on Death and Afterlife

description: A major form of religious expression is the various practices and rituals performed by individuals and the community. Various ritual theories and approaches will be examined along with different examples of religious ritual expressions.
title: Ritual and Religion

description: A consideration of various historical and thematic critiques of religion, including the development of modern agnosticism, atheism and in recent times, the ‘new atheism’.
title: Atheism

description: Nature of religion through a study of religious transformations in Africa.
title: Transformations of Religion in Africa

description: An examination of the beliefs, practices and developments of new religious movements of both Eastern and Western origins (e.g. Krishna Consciousness, Transcendental Meditation, Unification Church, Children of God, etc.).
title: New Religious Movements

description: Critical examination of social theories of religion and religious perspectives on ethical issues of social, economic, and political consequence in contemporary cultures.
title: Religion and Social Morality

description: An exploration of the various literary genres that make up the sixty-six books of the Bible, understood as a compilation of human literature reflecting millennia of communal struggle, vision, and engaged reception.
title: The Bible as Literature

description: Comparative and theoretical discussion of various traditions, Eastern and Western, regarding the object of religious belief and devotion.
title: God and Transcendence

description: An examination of religious depictions of supernatural evil agents and forces in the light of their role in the experience of good/evil, suffering/happiness, and existence/death.
title: Chaos, Demons and Monsters

description: An examination of the complex interplay of religious traditions and imperial projects. The development of religion in response to engagement with other cultures, religions and traditions brought on by colonialism, as well as the religious construction and categorization of these others, will be considered through comparative, historical, literary and/or thematic lenses. Modern responses to colonialism as well as discussions of multiculturalism and immigration may be discussed as they relate to religion.
title: Religion, Empire and Colonialism

description: A study of the complex relationship between religion and politics, including nationalism and political religions. Topics may include the origin of apartheid in South Africa, Black Theology, the rise of the New Christian Right in America, Hindu and Islamic political movements, and various forms of Fascism including the Nazi movement.
title: Religion and Politics

description: Reform, revivalist and sectarian movements and significant thinkers in Modern Islam.
title: Islam in the Modern World

description: A survey of the basic religious ideas, texts, figures, and practices in Islam, including their historical development.
title: Islam

description: The history, doctrines, literature and leading figures of traditions including Confucianism, Taoism and Shinto. Buddhism is not considered.
title: East Asian Religious Traditions

description: Comparative study of philosophical issues of religious interest arising from diverse cultures.
title: Cross-Cultural Philosophy of Religion

description: A comparative and critical examination of a specific topic within Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. Possible topics include: Material Culture, Pilgrimage, and Scriptural Exegesis.
title: Comparative Studies in Western Religions

description: An introduction to the major practices, beliefs, institutions and religious literature of the Jewish religion, as developed from antiquity to modern times.
title: Introduction to Judaism

description: Topics may include an overview of a specific religious tradition, an examination of religious expressions in a particular context, a thematic study of a religion or religions, or a methodological approach to the study of religion.
title: Topics in Religious Studies

description: Systematic instruction in research methods, academic writing, and the practice of critical analysis in the field of Religious Studies. Besides practical instruction, students will be introduced to a variety of methods and theories used in the academic study of religion.
title: Research and Critical Inquiry in Religious Studies

description: An examination of the complex interrelationship between understandings and constructions of gender, sexuality and Religion as they arise in the context of several religious traditions.
title: Gender, Sex and Religion

description: Study of formative Christianity in its political, social and religious contexts with particular attention to its origins within Second Temple Judaism.
title: From Jesus to Christ: 100 BCE-200 CE

description: Examination of social, economic, cultural, religious and political factors that influenced the evolution of early Christian identities as expressed through doctrine, rituals, practices, clerical structures and scripture.
title: Paganism and Christianity: 200-800 CE

description: An overview of medieval Christianity and of various renaissance and early modern Protestant and Catholic Reform movements.
title: Scholastics, Mystics and Reformers: Christianity 800-1600 CE

description: An overview of the Christian response to modernity, from the early modern and enlightenment periods through to the contemporary period.
title: Modern Christianity: 1600 - Present

description: The relationship between religion and science with emphasis on contemporary discussions regarding the intersection of religious thought and theories in the natural sciences.
title: Religion and Science

description: Consideration of issues of public environmental concern from the perspectives of religious studies and ethics. Possible topics include climate change, water depletion, environmental pollution, animal stresses, species/ecosystem decimation, and the climate refugee problem.
title: Religion and the Environment

description: The intersection of religion with popular culture is explored through specific topics.
title: Religion in Popular Culture

description: Detailed examination of a selected writer, topic, or intellectual current in recent religious thought. Possible topics include process thought, liberation theology, post-Holocaust theology, and existentialism.
title: Recent Religious Thought
prereqs: At least one 300-level Nature of Religion course (see Table of Streams at beginning of Department offerings).

description: Significance of the hermeneutical tradition for an understanding of religious issues and traditions with attention to the thought of Schleiermacher, Dilthey, Husserl, Heidegger, Gadamer, and Ricoeur among others.
title: Hermeneutics

description: Detailed study of selected topics in New Religious Movements.
title: Advanced Studies in New Religious Movements

description: An examination of existentialist thinkers from the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, contextualizing their work within both modernity and theist/atheist discourses.
title: Existentialism
prereqs: At least one 300-level Religious Studies course.

description: A critical examination of Asian philosophical and religious thinkers.
title: Advanced Studies in Asian Thought
prereqs: Philosophy 335 or at least one 300-level Religious Studies course.

description: A critical examination of various theories used in the academic study of religion.
title: Theories of Religion
prereqs: Religious Studies 377 plus one other 300-level Religious Studies course.

description: In-depth study of the historical developments of Hinduism (Vedic, Classical, Medieval, Modern) in a seminar or independent study format.
title: Advanced Studies in Hinduism

description: A seminar course that focuses on selected traditions, or philosophical or historical themes, such as Madhyamaka, Yogacara, T'ien T'ai, Hua Yen, Zen, Pure Land, Nyingma, Kargyud, Abhidharma, Tathagatagarbha, and Dhyana.
title: Advanced Studies in Buddhism

description: A seminar course that focuses on selected topics related to the Confucian, Taoist or Shinto tradition. Buddhism is not considered.
title: Advanced Studies in East Asian Religions

description: Advanced comparative study of selected philosophical issues of religious interest arising from diverse cultures.
title: Advanced Topics in Cross-Cultural Philosophy of Religion

description: Selected topics in Jewish practices, institutions, beliefs and religious literature. Possible topics include: Jewish Movements of the Second Temple Era; Jewish Rituals and Observances; Midrash and Jewish Biblical Interpretation; Law and Religion in Judaism; Jewish Philosophy and Theology; Judaism in the Modern World; Kabbalah and Jewish Mysticism.
title: Advanced Studies in Judaism

description: Selected readings, in English translation, from the three major divisions (Pentateuch, Prophets, and Writings) of the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament. Covers topics such as creation, miracles in Egypt, ark of the covenant, sacrifice, prophecies of the Bible, and biblical views of death and immortality.
title: Further Studies in the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament

description: A topical examination of developments in current research in such areas as: gender theory, post-colonialism, philosophy and religion, feminist theology, feminist evaluation of traditional religious structures, or interdisciplinary work in the reconstruction of women's religiosity.
title: Contemporary Issues in Women and Religion

description: A seminar course examining topics, personalities and movements in Christianity from its origins to its modern and contemporary developments.
title: Advanced Studies in Christianity

description: Study of religious texts in original languages such as Hebrew, Sanskrit, Tibetan, Chinese or Japanese.
title: Reading Religious Texts in Primary Languages

description: Students will complete an independent research project on a topic within their area of concentration in Religious Studies and present their research in a seminar setting.
title: Senior Project Seminar
prereqs: Religious Studies 377 and 6 units (1.0 full-course equivalent) at the 400 or 500 level in Religious Studies.

description: Students compose a major research paper under the close supervision of a member of the Department and defend the thesis before an examining committee.
title: Honours Thesis
prereqs: Religious Studies 377 and 6 units (1.0 full-course equivalent) at the 400 or 500 level in Religious Studies.

description: Advanced study of a particular topic under the direction of a faculty member. Qualified students will be supervised through a session of independent study.
title: Directed Independent Study
prereqs: Completion of 6 units (1.0 full-course equivalent) in Religious Studies at the 300 level and 3 units (0.5 full-course equivalent) in Religious Studies at the 400 level and consent of the Department.

title: Studies in the Nature of Religion

description: Selected topics on critical discourses in the study of religion.
title: Selected Topics on Critical Discourses in the Study of Religion
Specialized Studies in the Nature of Religion
Studies in the Nature of Religion

description: Advanced topics on critical discourses in the study of religion.
title: Advanced Topics on Critical Discourses in the Study of Religion

description: Overview of the risk management process and risk management methods. Emphasis on personal risk management, including auto, homeowners, life, health and disability insurance.
title: Introduction to Risk Management and Insurance
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business or the Actuarial Science program, and successful completion of 30 units (5.0 full-course equivalents) including Economics 201.

description: Examines the role that life and health insurance plays in securing individuals' financial futures, whether ensuring family security, or preserving the value produced by the time and energy spent building a business. Topics include wealth transfer to the next generation as well as protection of income and assets. The best fit for different types of policies available at different stages in life will also be examined.
title: Protecting your Family and Wealth
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business or the Actuarial Science program, and Finance 317 or Risk Management and Insurance 317.

description: The nature of employee benefits as a major component of the compensation package. Group life and group health insurance, pensions and other retirement programs, workers' compensation, unemployment insurance, social security and other social insurance plans. Insurer group operations, reinsurance and the legal aspects of employee benefits and social insurance programs.
title: Employee Benefits and Social Insurance
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business or the Actuarial Science program, and Finance 317 or Risk Management and Insurance 317.

description: Examines risk management for commercial property and liability exposures. The first half of the course focuses on common property loss exposures that firms face and examines methods of handling such risks. The second half focuses on liability exposures of commercial enterprises, including premises and operations liability, product liability, employment practices liability and director's and officers' liability.
title: Managing Commercial Property and Liability Risks
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business.

description: Combines a fundamental understanding of insurance and risk management with current issues confronting the insurance industry and risk managers.
title: Selected Topics in Risk Management and Insurance
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Risk Management and Insurance 317.

description: A study of the various methods used to finance the operational risks of commercial enterprises. Key topics addressed are: loss forecasting, insurance, alternative risk financing, reinsurance  and environmental risk management.
title: Advanced Topics in Risk Management and Insurance
prereqs: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Risk Management and Insurance 317.

description: Risk management strategies with emphasis on the management of operational and hazard risks. Topics include risk identification and assessment; organizational responsibility for risk management; risk mitigation; risk financing; crisis management, and business continuity planning.
title: Managing Risks and Disasters
prereqs: Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

description: France, Italy and Spain: cultures of the Mediterranean.
title: Topics in Romance Culture

description: Major authors of the Italian Renaissance whose works have influenced artists and writers in England, France and Spain.
title: Italian Literature of the Renaissance

description:
Topics in Romance Languages, Literatures and Cultures. Format and content may vary from year to year.
		399.02 Landscapes in Mediterranean Literature and Film
title: Topics in Romance Languages

description: Discussion of selected topics dealing with Romance languages, literatures and cultures. Format and content may vary from year to year.
title: Advanced Topics in Language and Culture
prereqs: One of French 227, 317, Italian 303 or Spanish 303.

description: Introductory course to Russian in its cultural context. The basic phenomena of Russian, the principles of language learning, strategies for observing and interpreting cultural phenomena.
title: Introductory Russian

description: First semester of a three-semester sequence of four-skills language learning, covering the principal elements of modern Russian
title: Russian I

description: The second semester of a three-semester sequence of four-skills language learning, covering the principal elements of modern Russian.
title: Russian II

description: The third semester of a three-semester sequence of four-skills language learning, covering the principal elements of modern Russian.
title: Russian III

description:
Distinctive features in the development of Russian civilization and thought.
		317.01. Multiculturalism, Russian Style
		317.02. The Creation of National Images
		317.03. Russian Cultural History Through Film
title: Topics in Russian Civilization and Thought

description: Strategies for accelerated proficiencies in the areas of vocabulary, the deciphering of written and oral texts and the relating of learned linguistic patterns to communi­cative contexts, with attention to appropriate discourse level in a variety of situations.
title: Intermediate Russian I

description: A continuation of Russian 331.
title: Intermediate Russian II

description: Selected texts by author, genre or period designed to explore issues of significance in the context of Russian culture.
title: Russian Literature in Translation

description: Overview of Russian literature of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries in a historical perspective, with attention to issues of particular significance in Russian literary culture. Initial experience of literary analysis on the basis of diverse Russian texts.
title: Russian Literature of the Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries

description: Selected significant issues in Russian culture, as manifested in written and/or oral texts, with particular attention to language function and usage.
title: Current Issues in Russian Culture

description: Independent study course. Project with inter-cultural theme, derived from an immersion experience, most likely abroad. Permission MUST be obtained before embarking on the immersion experience or enrolling in this course.
title: Inter-Cultural Immersion Experience I
prereqs: Consent of the Department. Departmental permission to enrol in this course depends on a faculty member's agreement to sponsor the course of study. To obtain that agreement, a student must first discuss the project with a faculty member orally, then present in written form a coherent and well-formulated project which will demonstrate learning (guidelines are available).

description: An advanced course in the use of Russian, including experiential learning in the form of a practicum, leading to supervised "teaching" in a suitable lower-level language class.
title: Advanced Russian I: The Consolidating Year

description: A continuation of Russian 401.
title: Advanced Russian II: The Consolidating Year

description: Cross-cultural comparison of events, cultural patterns, historical periods, or social movements which find a parallel in more than one of the cultural traditions represented in the Department. The language of instruction is English.
title: Cross-Cultural Explorations

description: Development of a topic, issue, period or author introduced in Russian 361. Topic for current year is listed in the Schedule of Classes.
title: Topics in Russian Literature

description: Concentration on a linguistic and/or cultural topic in its historical development.
title: Topics in Russian Language and Culture from a Historical Perspective

description: Independent study course. Project with inter-cultural theme, derived from an immersion experience at an advanced level, most likely abroad. Permission MUST be obtained before embarking on the immersion experience or enrolling in this course.
title: Inter-Cultural Immersion Experience II
prereqs: Russian 397 and consent of the Department. Departmental permission to enrol in this course depends on a faculty member's agreement to sponsor the course of study. To obtain that agreement, a student must first discuss the project with a faculty member orally, then present in written form a coherent and well-formulated project which will demonstrate learning (guidelines are available).

description: An independent research project on a topic that is not normally a part of the program's course offerings.
title: Independent Study
prereqs: Consent of the Department. Departmental permission to enrol in this course depends on a faculty member's agreement to sponsor the project.

description: Centred on a professor's current research project, the course will engage senior students as members of a collaborative research team. Independent research, discussion, group presentations, dissemination of results in an appropriate venue.
title: Research Seminar

description: The Honours project for Honours students in their final year.
title: Honours Project

description: This course will focus on the management, analysis, interpretation and communication of research results. Students will also examine and critique research design using examples from the primary literature in a multidisciplinary context.
title: Research Design and Statistical Analysis
prereqs: Completion of at least 24 units (4.0 full-course equivalents) and registration in the Natural Sciences Program or consent of the Director.

description: Elements of writing and reviewing scientific reports, use and enhancement of library skills, ethical principles of reviewing reports, and exposure to the literature of science. Papers and reviews will be transmitted electronically.
title: Writing and Reviewing Scientific Reports
prereqs: Any 200-level course offered by the Faculty of Science.

description: Students will develop a well-rounded perspective and appreciation of science by investigating the nature of scientific inquiry and critically assessing key historical and contemporary achievements in science.
title: Scientific Explorations

description: Exploration of the interaction among science and non-science areas in various ways including by written and oral presentations.
title: Science in Society
prereqs: Completion of at least 54 units (9.0 full-course equivalents) and registration in the Natural Sciences program or consent of the Director.

description: The science behind nuclear energy production including nuclear reactions, reactor design, waste disposal and historical and proposed accidents.
title: Fundamentals of Nuclear Energy Production
prereqs: Engineering Energy and Environment 355 and Physics 223 or 255, or one of Physics 301, 323, or 325, or consent of the Director.

description: The chemical and physical basis of fuel cells.
title: Fundamentals of Fuel Cells
prereqs: Engineering Energy and Environment 355; Physics 223 or 255, or consent of the Director.

description: Intended to achieve integration and interdisciplinarity within the Natural Sciences program.
title: Project Course in Natural Sciences
prereqs: Completion of at least 75 units (12.5 full-course equivalents) and registration in the Natural Sciences program or consent of the Director.

description: A comprehensive research project under the direction of staff member(s) in the Faculty of Science. Research projects may be disciplinary or interdisciplinary in nature. Interdisciplinary projects may involve more than one Science discipline or a Science discipline combined with a non-Science discipline.
title: Research Project in Natural Sciences
prereqs: Registration in the Natural Sciences Honours program and/or consent of the Director.

description: Lectures, seminars, tutorials and/or research project leading to a focused examination of a topic from interdisciplinary perspective.
title: Experiential Learning in Science - Special Topics

description: Students spend one term as an intern in a government, non-profit or private-sector organization under the auspices of an agency or organization that has a Co-operation Agreement with the University of Calgary.
title: Field Placement
prereqs: Consent of the Faculty of Science and acceptance to a program offered by the agency or organization that has a Co-operation Agreement with the University of Calgary.

description: The nature of solar radiation and how that energy may be captured for useful energy production.
title: Principles of Solar Energy
prereqs: Engineering Energy and Environment 355 or consent of the Director.

description: Intended to achieve integration across the interdisciplinary energy, environment and economy programs.
title: Project Course in Sustainable Energy, Environment and Economy
prereqs: Completion of at least 75 units (12.5 full-course equivalents) and registration in the Energy and the Environment Specialization, the Energy Management Concentration or the Energy Science Concentration, or consent of the Director.

description: An introduction to the scientific fundamentals of hydroelectric energy production. Includes an examination of the technologies and potential for developing hydroelectricity, along with the environmental, societal, and economic issues surrounding its development.
title: Principles of Hydroelectric Energy
prereqs: Engineering Energy and Environment 355 or consent of the Director.

description: An introduction to the scientific fundamentals of hydroelectric energy production. Includes an examination of the technologies and potential for developing hydroelectricity, along with the environmental, societal, and economic issues surrounding its development.
title: Principles of Geothermal Energy
prereqs: Engineering Energy and Environment 355 or consent of the Director.

description: An introduction to the roles, uses, and impacts of science and technology within society. Using an inquiry-based approach, students will investigate topics such as the scientific method, gender and technology, the role of experts in policy matters, and public engagement with science and technology.
title: Introduction to Science, Technology and Society

description: Examines the definition of technology and major questions concerning the relations between technology and society
title: Technology Within Contemporary Society

description: A case study analysis of the practice of science as a human activity. The theories linking the emergence of modern science to western culture are considered. An analysis of ideas of the social structure of scientific activity including: the role of examples in forming scientific theories, the value system of scientists in both basic research and applied research environments, "individual genius" vs multiple discovery, and the influence of "leading" figures. The linkages of scientific activity with other cultural dimensions are explored and the bases for formulation of "science policy" are considered.
title: Science in Society

description: A study of the implications of information technology for political, social and economic organization, individual psychology, and concepts of knowledge. Historical, ethical and legal implications will be discussed.
title: New Media, Technology, and Society

description: Examination and analysis of Canadian science policy and technology development. Factors which influence policies and strategies, and factors which should influence them. Evaluation of success and failures through case studies and policy analysis.
title: Canadian Science Policy and Technology Development

description: An examination of selected topics in Science, Technology and Society. See Schedule of Classes for current topic(s).
title: Special Topics in Science, Technology and Society

description: Examines how science and concerns over science have been 'made public' via emergent forms of media including novels, radio, television, film, and the Internet, and how various publics have enabled scientific transformations.
title: Publics and Science
prereqs: Completion of at least 48 units (8.0 full-course equivalents).

description: Examines the relationship between politics and technology, and how these shape and structure everyday life. Particular attention will be paid to the ways in which decisions about science and technology fit or do not fit with democratic ideals. Sample topics include democracy and technology; technologies as forms of governance; use of new media in politics; online activism; and politicization of science.
title: Politics and Technology
prereqs: Completion of at least 48 units (8.0 full-course equivalents).

description: Supervised individual study of a special topic.
title: Research in Selected Topics

description: This course treats topics in the formulation of science, technology, and/or innovation policy. It deals with the knowledge that shapes government, industry and public perceptions of science and technology issues, and how that knowledge is produced, interpreted and absorbed by the policy-making process. The course is intended for senior students in the Science, Technology and Society major or minor, or students with appropriate course preparation in related disciplines such as economics or political science.
title: Topics in Science and Technology Policy Research
prereqs: Completion of 9 units (1.5 full-course equivalents) in Science, Technology and Society at the 300 level or higher, or permission of the Department.

description: An integrative seminar on the central themes of science and technology studies.
title: Integrative Seminar
prereqs: Two of Science, Technology and Society 325, History 477, Philosophy 367, Sociology 435.

description: Selected works from the literatures of Central European countries in the twentieth century with particular attention to the impact of successive totalitarian régimes and issues associated with post-totalitarian societies.
title: Modern East-European Literature in Translation

description: Provides an overview of the profession of social work and the social policy context within which it is practiced.
title: Introduction to Social Work

description: Examination of knowledge, values, and skills pertaining to the practice of generalist social work practice in rural, remote, and Aboriginal communities.
title: Generalist Practice in Context Theme Course

description: Individual preparation and presentation of major project on social work practice models in the local context.
title: Generalist Practice in Context Portfolio Project

description: Provides an introduction to knowledge generation relevant to generalist social work practice. Foundational concepts and approaches of various research methodologies will be introduced as ways of knowledge building to inform practice and influence policy within rural, remote and Indigenous contexts. Particular emphasis will be directed to the development of skills in critiquing published research studies through examination of design limitations, ethical issues as well as the cultural assumptions and biases underlying research paradigms. Additional attention will be paid to contextually relevant evaluation of social work practice and services.
title: Research in Context Theme Course

description: Focuses on theory and practice to enhance interviewing skills within an environment sensitive to issues of diversity, culture, gender, power and language. Particular emphasis will be given to skill development, critical reflection and practical application within rural, remote and Indigenous contexts. This course may be offered in various formats (e.g. blended, block, evening and weekends).
title: Interviewing in Context

description: Issues of diversity, colonization, and intergroup relations associated with the practice of social work in rural, remote, and Aboriginal communities.
title: Diversity and Oppression Theme Course

description: Individual preparation and presentation of major project assessing local policies and programs with respect to diversity issues and colonial assumptions.
title: Diversity and Oppression Portfolio Project

description: Intervention approaches and skills for the practice of generalist social work in rural, remote, and Aboriginal communities.
title: Social Work Methods Theme Course

description: Focuses on theory and practice relating to social work with individuals, families, groups, organizations and communities. Particular emphasis will be paid to skill development, critical reflection and practical application within rural, remote and Indigenous contexts. This course may be offered in various formats (e.g. blended, block, evening, and weekends).
title: Practice Skills in Context

description: Students will be introduced to basic research methodology and data analysis within a reflective practitioner model of practice. They will be asked to identify research concepts, methods and skills that promote enquiry-based practice and that enable them to read and apply findings from research. The focus of the course will be on thinking of research as an integral component of practice.
title: Research in Context

description: Focuses on the examination and integration of theoretical and practical understandings of professional social work practice. Topics covered include: critical thinking; ethical decision-making; knowledge of the associations to which social work professionals belong; professional writing; and self-care.
title: Professional Use of Self

description: Explores the nature of human behaviour and development in diverse environments and contexts (personal, community, social, and environmental) and explores the implications for social work practice and theory.
title: Human Development and Environments

description: Provides theoretical frameworks, including anti-oppressive social work concepts, as a foundation for reflective professional generalist social work.
title: Critical Approaches to Social Work Practice

description: Students will critically examine the issues of diversity and the power relations that form common links among the experiences of oppression and marginalization in Canadian society.
title: Social Work and Diversity

description: Provides an understanding of Canadian social policy, its impact on social justice and how it influences social work practice.
title: Social Policy and Social Justice

description: An introduction to theories and skills for communicating with people in a professional social work context. Generic interviewing and basic counselling skills from a generalist perspective of social work practice will be developed.
title: Practice and Evaluation with Individuals

description: An introduction to theories and skills for family-centred social work practice with families. There will be an emphasis on diversity in relation to family development issues, the stresses families face, family assessment techniques, and theories and practices of family intervention.
title: Practice and Evaluation with Families

description: An introduction to theories and skills for working with groups within a context of practice and assessment frameworks.
title: Practice and Evaluation with Groups

description: An introduction to theories and skills about community practice. The focus will be on understanding the basic value, ethical, strategic, evaluative and political issues involved in working for community change.
title: Practice and Evaluation with Communities

description: An introduction to theories and skills in the study of human service organizations. Examines organizational dynamics and how this impacts on professional practice, relationships with clients, and the potential for organizational change.
title: Practice and Evaluation with Organizations

description: Application of conceptual framework, experience, knowledge and skills within a specific practice setting.
title: Practicum I
prereqs: Completion of all required 300 level Social Work courses.

description: Integration of theory and practice within the context of the field practicum.
title: Integrative Seminar I
prereqs: Completion of all required 300 level Social Work courses.

description: Application of professional theory and skills in supervised social work practice settings.
title: Practicum II
prereqs: Completion of all required 300 level Social Work courses. University Transfer Route: Social Work 410 and 411.

description: Advanced integration of concepts, perspectives and skills with experiences, developing conceptual frameworks of practice.
title: Integrative Seminar II
prereqs: Completion of all required 300 level Social Work courses. University Transfer Route: Social Work 410 and 411.

title: Selected Topics: Social Work Interventions
prereqs: Social Work 353 or 355, 363 or 367, 383, 361 or 385 and 365 or 388, or admission into the Post-Diploma route.

title: Selected Topics: Fields of Practice
prereqs: Social Work 353 or 355, 363 or 367, 383, 361 or 385 and 365 or 388, or admission into the Post Diploma route.

title: Selected Topics: Practice with Selected Populations
prereqs: Social Work 353 or 355, 363 or 367, 383, 361 or 385 and 365 or 388, or admission into the Post-Diploma route.

title: Selected Topics: Contexts for Practice
prereqs: Social Work 353 or 355, 363 or 367, 383, 361 or 385 and 365 or 388, or admission into the Post-Diploma route.

description: An examination of the relationship between knowledge, values, ethics and power and how they shape interventions in social work.
title: History and Foundation of the Profession

description: A basic understanding of social work practice theory with respect to work with individuals, families and groups.
title: Practice with Individuals, Families and Groups

description: A basic understanding of social work practice theory with respect to work with organizations and communities.
title: Practice with Organizations and Communities

description: Offers experiential learning aimed at developing basic professional competencies and practice skills along with critical self-reflection.
title: Professional Communication and Interviewing

description: An exploration of the social, political and economic forces, social movements and social structures that are transforming the Canadian welfare state and the practice of social work.
title: Social Policy and Social Justice

description: Direct and indirect social work practice opportunities with professional supervision.
title: Foundational Field Practicum

description: Human development and diversity within a social work context.
title: Human Behaviour in the Environment

description: Provides the conceptual and theoretical foundation for students to acquire the skills to practice in Social Work.
title: Models of Practice

description: An overview of social work research topics and issues.
title: Issues in Social Work Research

description: Policies and their impacts on the delivery of clinical work will be examined.
title: Policy as Context for Clinical Work

description: Various clinical change applications will be examined and critiqued.
title: Comparative Approaches to Change

description: An introduction to preparing a thesis proposal.
title: Thesis Research

description: Specific issues involved in the effective application of clinical approaches will be studied.
title: Clinical Social Work Applications

description: Research as utilized in the clinical arena will be the focus of this course.
title: Evidence and Clinical Practice

description: The focus of this course is leadership in policy practice and in particular policy advocacy at all levels of policy (i.e., organizational, community, and provincial or national levels).
title: Influencing Policy Development

description: Directed toward helping prepare leaders for “best practice” across the range of sectors and roles in which human service leaders work.
title: Leadership Theories in Action

description: A practical course that will emphasize networked and collaborative approaches to leadership in a global context.
title: Leading Organizations and Communities

description: Explores social welfare policy in Canada and in a globalizing world, the current roles of social welfare policy, and the roles they should have.
title: Social Policy

description: Examines issues in international social development.  There will be an emphasis on analysis of the social forces and conditions giving rise to different models of social development, and on what each of these alternative models tends to produce in terms of social welfare policies and programs.
title: International Social Development

description: This set of modules will give students tools for social change.
title: Advanced International Social Work Modules

description: International and Community Development Research is designed to provide methodological knowledge and skills specifically oriented to community-based practice abroad or in Canada.
title: Social Work Research for International and Community Methods

description: Selected topics related to area of specialization or interest.
title: Special Topics Seminar I

description: Selected topics related to an area of specialization or interest.
title: Special Seminar II

description: This course will provide students with a working understanding for the study and nature of the theoretical and practical issues underlying the application of the research process to professional and leadership practice.
title: Research as a Foundation for Leadership

description: Extends students’ abilities to identify, assess, and utilize research knowledge as a problem-solving tool in social work.
title: Becoming an Evidence-Based Leader

description: Direct and indirect Social Work practice opportunities with professional supervision in student's area of specialization or interest.
title: Advanced Practicum

description: Critical examination of the issues of diversity and the power relations that form common links among the experiences of oppression and marginalization in Canadian society.
title: Diversity, Oppression and Social Justice

description: Advanced selected topics related to area of specialization or interest.
title: Special Topics Seminar II

description: A concluding course offered as final component of student's course work. Allows doctoral students and the instructor to engage in a series of research colloquia, thereby facilitating critical analysis, feedback and synthesis of materials covered and skills learned in other course work. This process will help students to develop conceptual and methodological skills.
title: Integrative Research Colloquia

description: An exploration of major philosophical issues that have shaped social work's diverse approaches to knowledge building and research methods. The relevance of this exploration to the student's area of interest is emphasized.
title: Research Foundations: Epistemology and Professional Knowledge-Building

description: An exploration of the philosophical and ideological issues that have been historically important to the profession with respect to its conception of its ethics, mandate and practices. The relevance of this exploration to the student's area of interest in emphasized.
title: Theory, History and Philosophy: Values, Ethics and Professional Beliefs

description: Quantitative methodological and design options in social work research.
title: Research Methods I: Quantitative

description: Qualitative methodological and design options in social work research.
title: Research Methods II: Qualitative

description: Statistical analysis of quantitative data.
title: Quantitative Data Analysis

description: Advanced selected topics related to the PhD focus area.
title: Special Topics Seminar

description: Sociology as a discipline examines how the society in which we live influences our thinking and behaviour. An introduction to sociology will be provided through the study of society, social institutions, group behaviour and social change.
title: Introductory Sociology

description: An examination of the major institutions of Canadian society. Consideration given to the diversity of the Canadian population and to the dynamics of contemporary patterns of social change.
title: Canadian Society

description: A sociological exploration of the way genders are constructed and how they play-out at the level of individuals and institutions, and in diverse social contexts.
title: Sociology of Gender

description: The dynamics of Native Indian groups' relations with each other and the larger society. Topics include decolonization and relations with the state, demography, Indian organizations, Indian nationalism and nation-building, power, social class and public policy.
title: Sociology of First Nations in Canada

description: An historical and contemporary overview of First Nations’ life in Canada. Introduces the student to the Indian Act, treaties, economic development, education, demography, urbanization, popular culture and other topics.
title: Alberta Society

description: Univariate and bivariate statistics for survey data. Topics include cross tabular analysis, the normal distribution, confidence intervals for means, hypothesis testing, Chi-squared and F distributions and bivariate linear regression analysis. In labs students will use statistical software to analyse survey data.
title: Introductory Social Statistics I

description: Research processes including problem definition, data collection and analyses; quantitative and qualitative strategies. Students are expected to acquire skills through doing research.
title: Introductory Social Research Methods

description: Multivariate statistics for survey data; and measurement issues in quantitative research. Topics include reliability, multivariate tabular analysis, multiple regression, dummy variable regression, statistical interaction and path analysis. In labs students will use statistical software to test measurement and causal models.
title: Introductory Social Statistics II

description: Introduction to social factors influencing health, illness, and medicine. Topics covered may include the organization of medical institutions and occupations, the socialization of medical professionals, the social construction of illness, social determinants of health, and comparative health care systems and policy.
title: Sociology of Health and Illness

description: The presentation and analysis of theories of criminality and of non-criminal deviance, methods to uncover the incidence of deviance and criminality, a survey of forms of deviant and criminal behaviours, and the social and institutional responses to them.
title: Introduction to Deviance and Social Control

description: Introduction to the field of criminal justice in Canada from a sociological perspective. May include: examination of the definitions of crime; crime measurement; institutional responses to crime by the police, the courts and correctional services; and alternatives to the justice model.
title: Introduction to Criminal Justice

description: The development of sociological theory from the nineteenth century to the Second World War.
title: Classical Sociological Theory

description: The development of sociological theory from the Second World War to the present.
title: Contemporary Sociological Theory

description: A wide range of interdependent individual and social topics that influence our thinking, feeling, and behaviour. Topics may include social cognition, perception, social experience, group behaviour, social interaction, and emotions.
title: Social Psychology

description: A critical, theoretically-informed look at what it means to live in a society in which the forms and content of mass media/mass communication – and our uses of them – shape our lives in significant ways.
title: Mass Communication

description: Discusses the impact of urbanization on social relationships by analysing city living in historical and global perspective but also through local issues such as density and neighborhoods. The objective is to provide a sociological perspective on issues that cities are facing today.
title: Urban Sociology

description: Introduction to social demography – the study of population structure (size, composition and distribution) and processes (fertility, mortality and migration). Focuses on both empirical and theoretical relationships between demography, social change and structured inequality.
title: Population and Society

description: Introduction to the sociological study of social inequalities and stratification and the major theoretical explanations of social inequalities.
title: Social Stratification

description: A sociological examination of family life in all its multiple and changing forms. Topics may include key transitions and common practices in family life; gender, sexuality and family life, and family life in cross-cultural context.
title: Sociology of Families

description: Social and institutional factors associated with aging in modern society.
title: Sociology of Aging

description: Introduction to the forms of ethnic and racial dynamics in selected cases around the world. Such concepts as identity, ethnicity, race, racialization, racism, assimilation, integration, pluralism, colonialism, post-colonialism, transnationalism and diasporas are examined in theoretical and cross-national contexts.
title: Sociology of Ethnicity and Racialization

description: An introduction to the theories and concepts utilized by sociologists to interpret religious behaviour and the organization of religion.
title: Sociology of Religion

description: A sociological perspective for gaining a better understanding of the meaning and nature of work. Provides an overview of core concepts and current topics fundamental to understanding work in society.
title: Sociology of Work

description: Organized around the theme of social problems in sport, this course examines sports-related behaviour, consumption, and sponsorship. A variety of approaches shows how sport is socially constructed and embodies different meanings for different groups of people.
title: Sociology of Sport

description: The thesis is a research project under the direction of the department. In the seminar, students will discuss and present their projects, and other relevant topics.
title: Sociology Honours Thesis and Seminar
prereqs: Sociology 313 and consent of the Department.

description: Selected themes as announced by the Department.
title: Special Topics in Sociology

description: Selected themes and issues in the sociology of gender relations as announced by the Department.
title: Special Topics in Gender Relations

description: A macro-level examination of Canadian social structure including a socio-developmental analysis of selected Canadian institutions such as bilingualism, regionalism, multiculturalism, multinational corporations, and ethnic stratification. Critical examination of sociological models for the study of Canadian society.
title: Special Topics in Canadian Social Structure

description: Considers aspects of the lived body and the body as object of social construction, modification, and regulation.
title: Sociology of the Body

description: An advanced study of health in a social context. Examines the social determinants of health and illness outcomes along with their implications for public policies conducive to better health.
title: Social Determinants of Health

description: Research methods such as participant observation, naturalistic observation, interviewing, non-reactive techniques, and life histories, and methodological issues such as gaining access to subjects, and issues pertaining to the ethics of research.
title: Qualitative Research Methods

description: Advanced analysis of selected themes and issues in the sociology of health and illness, as announced by the Department.
title: Special Topics in the Sociology of Health and Illness

description: Advanced study of contemporary issues in the research in deviance and crime.
title: Special Topics in Deviance and Criminology

description: Explanations of the criminal activities of young people including an assessment of treatment strategies and legal regimes developed in response to this behaviour.
title: The Sociology of Youth Crime

description: An exploration of violence in a variety of situations and social institutions and more general patterns of victimization in contemporary society.
title: The Sociology of Violence

description: Comparative social organization of the criminal justice system from a sociological perspective; special attention to and analysis of the structure of the Canadian criminal justice system.
title: The Social Organization of Criminal Justice

description: Sociological problems regarding the origin, impact and definition of law, dispute resolution, and the relationship between law and social change.
title: The Sociology of Law
prereqs: Sociology 327 and 313.  Sociology 325, 331 and 333 are recommended.

description: The study of knowledge as a social practice; theories of knowledge, representation and interpretation; practical knowledge in everyday life; the role of organized knowledge in social domains such as science, biomedicine, bureaucracy, social service administration and professional occupations.
title: The Sociology of Knowledge
prereqs: Sociology 331 and 333 or equivalents.  Sociology 313 is recommended.

description: An advanced study of social processes and interactions of persons in groups with some methodological considerations.
title: Special Topics in Social Psychology
prereqs: Sociology 341 and 313.  Sociology 331 and 333 are recommended.

description: Visual representation in contemporary society. Social Practices of making and using Visual images, such as photographs. The use of visual methods in sociological research.
title: Visual Sociology

description: Critical analysis of theories of urban institutional and ecological characteristics. Emphasis is on comparative data derived from a sample of world cities.
title: Special Topics in Urban Sociology
prereqs: Sociology 313 and 353.  Sociology 331 and 333 are recommended.

description: A social movement perspective on working class struggle and accommodation in capitalist societies. Historical and contemporary movements will be considered, with an emphasis on Canada.
title: Worker Movements and Labour Unions

description: An introduction to the structure and form of ethnic (racial) group relations in Canada. Contemporary relations will be analysed from a historical perspective.
title: Ethnic Relations in Canada
prereqs: Sociology 313 and 375.  Sociology 331 and 333 are recommended.

description: Selected themes and issues in the sociology of families as announced by the Department.
title: Special Topics in the Sociology of Families
prereqs: Sociology 371 and 313.  Sociology 331 and 333 are recommended.

description: Advanced analysis of selected themes and issues in race and ethnic relations within the framework of theory and research.
title: Special Topics in Race and Ethnic Relations
prereqs: Sociology 313 and 375.  Sociology 331 and 333 are recommended.

description: A study of the process of change and modernization in the developing areas of the world.
title: Sociology of Development

description: Selected themes and issues in the sociology of work as announced by the Department.
title: Special Topics in the Sociology of Work
prereqs: Sociology 313 and 393.  Sociology 331 and 333 are recommended.

description: Arranged for various topics of Sociology on the basis of special interest and need.
title: Conference Course in Sociology
prereqs: Sociology 313, 315, and 333 and at least two Sociology courses at the 400 level.

description: Arranged for various topics of Sociology on the basis of special interest and need.
title: Seminar in Special Topics in Sociology
prereqs: Consult Department for assignment to Faculty member.

title: Seminar in Sociology of Health and Illness

description: Multiple regression with applications to sociological research, with topics such as regression diagnostics, categorical predictors, non-linear relationships, logistic regression, and testing of mediation and moderation.
title: Social Statistics: The General Linear Model
prereqs: Consent of the Department. (Sociology 311 and 315 normally required.)

description: Advanced study in the theory and practice of quantitative research methods. Topics may include the logic of causality, mixed methods designs, sampling, measurement, survey construction and implementation.
title: Seminar in Quantitative Research Methods

description: Advanced study in the theory and practice of qualitative research methods. Topics may include participant observation, in-depth interviews, narrative analysis, conversation and discourse analysis, autoethnography, archival research, and feminist research methods.
title: Seminar in Qualitative Research Methods
Seminar on Families, Relationships, and Personal Life
Seminar in Sociology of Gender Relations

description: Seminar on selected topics. Consult Department for details.
title: Doctoral Seminar in Sociology
Selected Topics in Advanced Methodological Issues
Selected Topics in Advanced Quantitative Methods
Selected Topics in Advanced Qualitative Methods

description: Introduction to developing large-scale, quality software, from analysis of requirements, through design, implementation, and testing. Introduction to design for non-functional properties of software. Emphasis on individual skills.
title: Software Analysis and Design

description: Software architectures and design for non-functional software properties. Introduction to program comprehension skills including analysis of existing architectures.
title: Software Architecture

description: A comparison of alternative software processes emphasizing both their strengths and weaknesses. Addresses the human, social, societal, ethical, and organizational factors inherent in real-world software development. Emphasis on team development skills in a large-scale development project.
title: Software Development in Teams and Organizations

description: Concepts, methods, techniques, processes, and tools for software testing.
title: Software Testing

description: Introduction to elicitation, modelling, expression and validation of the requirements. Techniques and methodologies for requirements engineering. Applications of requirements engineering to the management of the software development lifecycle.
title: Software Requirements Engineering

description: Topics of the next generation of software development methods, technologies, or tools.
title: Advanced Topics in Software Engineering
prereqs: Consent of either the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering or the Department of Computer Science.

description: Analysis of methods, tools, and techniques for software process improvement and software project management as an effort to achieve quality software products.
title: Software Process and Project Management
prereqs: One of Software Engineering 403 or 411, or Computer Science 301 or 451.

description: An overview of software engineering methods and technologies for developing web-based software systems.
title: Web-Based Systems

description: Investigation and application of agile software development practices.
title: Agile Software Engineering
prereqs: One of Software Engineering 401, 403, 411, or 443 or Computer Science 301 or 451.

description: The principles, processes, and applications of software reliability and software quality assurance.
title: Software Reliability and Software Quality

description: Software specification, verification, and validation using a mathematically rigorous technique.
title: Formal Methods
prereqs: One of Software Engineering 403 or 411 or Computer Science 301 or 451.

description: Analysing quality requirements of large-scale software. Performance analysis, testing, and tuning techniques. Evaluating software scalability. Capacity planning methodologies. Issues related to safety, security, and availability of software.
title: Software Performance Evaluation
prereqs: One of Software Engineering 301, Computer Engineering 493, or Computer Science 301, and one of Computer Science 457, Software Engineering for Engineers 413, or Computer Engineering 491.

description: Phenomena and approaches involved in the evolution and reuse of large-scale software, including design for modifiability and tool support. Strengths and weaknesses of industrially-current techniques as well as recent research results.
title: Fundamentals of Software Evolution and Reuse

description: A study of practical approaches of industrial relevance to students specializing in Software Engineering.
title: Industrial Topics in Software Engineering

description: A study of problems of particular interest to students specializing in Software Engineering.
title: Special Topics in Software Engineering

description: A study of problems of particular interest to students specializing in Software Engineering.
title: Special Topics in Software Engineering

description: The elicitation, modelling, expression, and validation of requirements.
title: Requirements Engineering I

description: Investigation and application of agile software development practices.
title: Agile Software Engineering

description: Product release planning covers systematic methods, tools and techniques for defining the functionality of a sequence of product releases in incremental development. The planning and re-planning is established as a systematic process trying to optimize resources available towards the functionality most requested by customers and stakeholders.
title: Software Release Planning
